on Cancer (IARC), which is a part of the WHO, has now categorized processed meats as “carcinogenic to humans”.
All of the scientists involved unanimously come to the same conclusion that eating meat, processed or not, is not a part of a healthy diet.
According to IARC’s evaluation of the studies done on the link between risk of cancer and eating red and processed meat, the IARC concludes that, "Red meat is probably carcinogenic to humans". Processed meat has been declared to be "carcinogenic to humans".

you can eat to replace the nutrients lost due to watery stool. Here are nine tasty options that may help to treat occasional diarrhea.
Not all bananas are the same. Dwarf bananas aren’t as sweet or dense as regular-sized ones. In fact, your standard yellow banana is quite large and full of starchy carbohydrates that help provide you with energy. Dwarf bananas, however, are smaller, sweeter, less acidic, and low in starches. This makes them the best kind to eat during or after an episode of diarrhea since they break down easily, promote hydration, and are high in potassium.

astronomers celebrated the finding of a candidate planet with liquid water, another alien world was recently announced with oceans that could actually consist of ice. In many ways, the world – dubbed GJ 436b (or, simply, GJ 436) – is stranger than most alien planets found in former times. It is only about 30 light years away from Earth and is one-fifth as massive as our own planet. Yet it is smaller and denser, with 15 times our planet’s gravity.
For instance, its star is known as Gliese 436, or GJ 436 for short, which is classified as a type of cool, dim star called a red dwarf. This makes it 40 per cent fainter than our sun but still more than 1,000 times brighter than our nearby sun-like star Proxima Cent

second installment in the series The Double Shadow is much more serious tone and is much more UF compared to The Accidental Sorceror. Non-scented and promoted in springtime plant journals, it is worth bearing with it through the harsher months.

Gutmann said the company could allow customers to disable the content protection features even as it simultaneously continues the development of its operating system. The security researcher said if companies want their products to be secure, they must disable some potential "safeness" burdens developers impose on gadget manufacturers.

Seeds of chillies in Mexico come from wild plants which are thought to have originated in Bolivia. It is a thin-fruited variety and sold over 240,000 tons in 2000.
Jalapeños are small chill peppers, about length of a fig 8 cm (3 in), and bright orange with a pointy tail. They are hot and very aromatic. They have very low vitamin C content.
For human consumption they are cleaned, dried then sold in markets. They are used by Mexican recipes to adapt salsas. They are recommended to be eaten whole.

talks in Cancun, cheers were raised when nations signed an agreement to halt deforestation within the next couple decades.
Yet there are plans afoot in some countries to ramp up rates of deforestation by reducing protections for rainforests, sacrificed on the altar of development and industry. Indonesia’s cloud forests and Congo’s forests are due for certain physical modification, according to plans laid by these developing countries, and their populations will be entitled to miss out on the vast array of benefits forests provide.
For deforestation to halt worldwide requires governments, so the thinking goes, that value biological resources more highly than projects manufacturers of carbon-emitting goods would like to run in the nations.
Equally global change efforts have great obstacles, including the policies in the forest nations where they hurt the most, the authors of a new report say.

Middle Ages. As a Platonizing Neoplatonist, he was fully committed to Orthodox Christianity but found in Plato the philosophical key with which to explain the Christian revelation. . Genetics can determine how men grow hair.
Vitamin D plays no role in male hair loss. Some studies had purported that low vitamin D levels might one day become the number-one cause of male hair loss. However, current research doesn’t support that relationship.
The current number-one cause of male hair loss is androgenetic alopecia. It’s what’s known as an autosomal inherited condition, which means the biological factors directing hair growth are passed down from parents to their children through their genes. So whatever the mother’s hair history was, that’s what most likely your pattern will be.
In the past, the prescription solutions for male hair loss were given topical with little cause for concern around the possible dangers of side effects. Most of them certainly were easy to understand and apply, including products such as Minoxidil or any number of brand name of fin

Clarithromycin does not usually have side effects when taken alone for preventing pneumonia or when taken for 3 days to treat a lower respiratory tract infection. However, it can cause a serious increase in the amount of a certain type of white blood cell called neutrophils when taken for longer periods of time. This can increase the risk of having a serious infection such as sepsis. Sepsis can cause death and requires hospitalization. It is important to continue to take clarithromycin until it is finished to prevent infections caused by the bacteria.

Note that, despite this deal, Amplidata's existed since 2008.
Amplidata is one of just a few vendors selling object-based storage. They do this using distributed object storage software - i.e. lots of caching instances of the software across lots of storage systems. Contrast this to commodity object storage in the cloud from the likes of AWS and pure flash HDS spin-in NANDrive and you have a broad number of providers in this market.
One motive is to extend their existing lines to capture the aggregate object storage market; Amplidata gives HGST access to this market while existing MetroNFS gives them access to the download market segment of object.

.Y.-bound Capital Corridor was en route from Portland, Ore., when it hit the construction equipment at just after 6 a.m. outside of Davis, California — about 160 miles northeast of San Francisco.
The locomotive of the train was going about 38 mph and the equipment was hit with about 150 pounds (68 kilograms) of force, Amtrak spokesman Marc Magliari said. The train, which had 137 passengers and nine crew members, came to a halt at the scene. No other injuries were reported.

The benefits of selling web services include working remotely or part time, customizing a package or service based on your own personal preferences, excellent earning potential and increased job satisfaction. Working as a reseller requires fast, efficient internet connections, cash for equipment, including working internet routers, telephone, computer and cash for startup costs, preferably a computer, Linux or a Mac, control panels and access to server space, a reliable company to give necessary support and product training, positive year round sales, business and marketing knowledge.

Division of Life Sciences at the Arizona State University Bob and Dolores Hope Center for Brain Health and Aging measure brain function using a scientifically validated tool called a Functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy (fNIRS) device. FNIRS works like a non-invasive functional MRI to measure blood flow changes associated with neural activity and can take less than 60 seconds to complete the cycle on the body from scanning to reviewing. FNIRS records passive signals from blood moving through brain tissue, and thus is “a useful tool for gaining a non-invasive understanding of the cerebrovascular response to a stimulus”, as medical scientists David G. T. Morgan and Amy K. Portman from the Center for Dementia Research and Education, The Black Dog Institute in Australia write in a 2012 published study on the device.

Four oil spill sites in Nigeria identified by the UN, which Shell has claimed to have had cleaned up by contractors since 2011, are still polluted and may never recover, a report said – with three spills said to have been completely untreated.
The report from Amnesty International, published on Thursday, examined oil spills on land and waterways in the Niger Delta caused by spills from six Shell pipelines since 2011. Amnesty said that two pipelines, the Bodo-Ogoni and Folu-Ajaokuta, were still polluting Nigerian waterways and clean-up had stalled on the two land spills – the Misanti Well 1 and Misanti Well 2.

Bedbugs carry a particular danger to people with allergies that are sensitive to their bite. Some symptoms are swelling, redness and irritation at the sites of bites — similar to a bee and wasp sting — but can last two to five weeks in extreme cases.
Even after the bugs are eradicated, many people will have itchiness and residual itch in their skin. But in extreme cases some people have developed a full-blown, severe allergic reaction to the bites, known as scabies, a skin infection.
Bedbugs are small enough to fit into cracks between floor boards and can live for up to a year!

The 20th century best-selling novelist Kurt Vonnegut was born on this day in 1922. The opening line of his 1963 classic Slaughterhouse-Five is memorable: “Billy Pilgrim has come unstuck in time.”
More interestingly, Billy Pilgrim knows one thing that a lot of other humans don’t seem to know but that scientists clearly understand today: The planet is definitely warming, as shown by the entire Earth science community, all year long. Despite a lot of corporate denial funding, the American public generally accepts this understanding.
Global warming is real, Earth Day is regular and Kurt Vonnegut is an American classic. And all of these are a perfect storm

an interstellar object passing close to our solar system.
Interstellar objects spotted passing by our solar system in recent years are completely different from comets and asteroids. The best known examples of these interlopers are 1I/'Oumuamua, a cigar-shaped object that slingshots around our solar system in a matter of months, and 2I/Borisov, which has a rotation period millennia longer than 'Oumuamua's.
We haven't discovered where either of these objects came from or what they are doing expanding the boundaries of our cosmic home, but that vague, non-specific mechanism recognizable to anyone who grew up watching 'Star Wars' is part of the reason some astronomers believe they were constructed and launched into (or escaped from) interstellar space by an alien civilization.

was known by white explorers only by the names of its native people. In ever expanding sweeps, as white settlers moved westward in search of land, gold, and water, whites forced the removal of native tribes and governments. This removed from the landscape any place name that sounded too Indian.
I am a Southerner, but I can attest to the opposite has been the story in that part of the country. In early days, the Appalachian region was largely blank. supernovae, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their resident planets and stripping away an Earth-like planet's atmosphere, making life possible on the surface of that planet unlikely. Other supernovae, meanwhile, are in a class known as core-collapse supernovae. These blasts are not only strong enough to kill any life nearby, but their remnants are rich in radioactive elements and are expected to have been responsible for enriching nearby star systems with the atomic ingredients that helped give rise to our solar system.
While core-collapse supernovae produce much of the heavy elements, it is the extended stellar and supernova debris that generally remains visible nowadays that seems the most unique. This so-called supernova debris is known as a remnant.
The type of supernova that is likely responsible for producing nearly all the heavy elements is the core-collapse variety

my bedroom window and I remember playing with the discarded wood from a heart-shaped tree – tracing different shapes into the bark with crayons and lipstick. My first observing experiment was testing the colours that stem cells could produce. From a tabletop microscope, I watched the mitochondria beat around my scorched lid crusts; a subtle pink tinge permeating the cells. General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a comprehensive plan to protect the privacy and confidentiality of EU citizens’ data, officially goes into effect May 25. As the EU’s data privacy watchdog – the Office of the Information Commissioner – shares data-related best practices with regulators worldwide, the legislation ultimately could impact consumers, businesses and corporations globally. The GDPR specifically includes a mandate for any company doing business in the EU to establish internal rules on the collection, use, monitoring, transfer and destruction of personal data – wherever it resides, as long as it concerns and affects Europeans. It has global ramifications for multinational corporations with sizable EU-centric revenues and European-based subsidiaries. What began as innocuous university project makes the transition to maturing Internet property and, in doing so, has changed the face of the Web itself. This blurring of the traditional lines that dominated the whole of the history of the Internet is in no small part a result of IPO valuation.
IPO valuation mythology for Facebook is so high — and has been for so long — that it is almost unrealistic to expect many, myself included, to believe the numbers when they finally come out. I love the fundamentals; I love the upside. The idea of a worldwide communication platform that is free of government surveillance, and that is instantly accessible with no friction from IP, perhaps most of all.

Antibiotics treat a variety of bacterial infections by inhibiting the function of the ribosome within the bacterial cell. In common with us humans, they use proteins called ribosomes to build new proteins. Without them, they cannot complete processes to incorporate new amino acids, such as to reproduce. The small molecules, called macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF), are known to correlate to inflammation and disease, such as metabolic syndrome and psoriasis. MIF have also been implicated in intestinal problems including diarrhoea and inflammation.

IBM on Tuesday announced a prepackaged and pretested clustered system aimed at the GLi (Grid Labs Initiative) type of large-scale computational research currently on the front burner at universities, national labs, and most major research centers worldwide.
The IBM Cluster 325 server, intended as a pilot production server for large-scale computational research projects, is built around the same IBM eServer 325 utilized in the company's BladeServers and two to six storage arrays, named Cluster Data Vault 250s. The system allows clients to add capacity as needed. It has been prepackaged to run either Linux (Red Hat Enterprise Linux or Novell SUSE Linux) or Windows operating systems. Marketers are employed in the public sector as well as the private sector.
Most people think of marketing as a strictly private sector activity, but the reality is people with sales and marketing backgrounds are hired by government agencies or private and nonprofit groups because they are creative and persuasive.
Marketing skills can be applied to a wide range of careers. In the private sector a marketer may help sell products, for example, or plan promotions. In government, marketers try to increase awareness and use of products as varied as food, medical instruments or taxes.

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), which is a part of the WHO, has now categorized processed meats as “carcinogenic to humans”.
All of the scientists involved unanimously come to the same conclusion that eating meat, processed or not, is not a part of a healthy diet.
According to IARC’s evaluation of the studies done on the link between risk of cancer and eating red and processed meat, the IARC concludes that, "Red meat is probably carcinogenic to humans". Processed meat has been declared to be "carcinogenic to humans".
[1] This puts processed meats such as ham and bacon as a possible human carcinogen, alongside substances such as tobacco and alcohol, according to the Associated Press (AP). Health News reported in January.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a fight between Republican lawmakers and President Barack Obama.
Americans will either see their nation run out of cash or face the possibility of default on July 31, a time when the federal government could run out of the ability to borrow money, unless the U.S. Congress acts to avert either of those outcomes.
Other current estimates and projections indicate that revenue coming into the federal government will be more than sufficient to cover its obligations due in about three weeks. However, that leaves open the possibility of the federal government failing to meet its obligations for the first time in its history on Aug. 3, according to Lew’s office.
Republican lawmakers have vowed to derail Obama’s health care law in negotiations over federal spending and borrowing authority.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for on-air shopping plans to spend three days sharing an all-day dedicated Black Friday block on WPVI, the ABC affiliate in Philadelphia that carries the QVC shopping channel in that market, the company said Tuesday. In a tradition that runs from Thanksgiving to retailer Cyber Monday in the following week, an assortment of products will be offered amid non-stop programming, QVC said. The emphasis will not only be on brands sold on the air but also new products, the company said.
Shows will feature Black Friday products, offerings that are first to TV, and existing programs with a QVC twist.
QVC has three separate techniques for reaching shoppers on these key days beyond the 54 hours the retailer sells live on the air: via catalog and web product links, on-air promotions and new offers that shoppers receive via e-mail.

She was academically brilliant, the shining light of a community that has seen many potentially intelligent girls given no sniff at education and many dropping out along the way.

From a pool of more than 100 applicants, just 10 got in, including 80 per cent of the top-performing students. But only half were actually able to qualify. That Bruen went on to collect multiple top marks in university and to graduate as an exemption rejected any gender stereotyping she may have encountered throughout her studies. In 2006, she was also the first woman to win an O’Donoghue Prize, given for graduates showing the highest academic performance.

Occasional diarrhea is a common occurrence. Most people will experience an episode of diarrhea at least once or twice a year that will disappear in a couple of days.
Luckily, there are many foods you can eat to replace the nutrients lost due to watery stool. Here are nine tasty options that may help to treat occasional diarrhea.
Not all bananas are the same. Dwarf bananas aren’t as sweet or dense as regular-sized ones. In fact, your standard yellow banana is quite large and full of starchy carbohydrates that help provide you with energy. Dwarf bananas, however, are smaller, sweeter, less acidic, and low in starches. This makes them the best kind to eat during or after an episode of diarrhea since they break down easily, promote hydration, and are high in potassium.

The day Jeff Deardorff has been waiting a lifetime for has arrived.
Major League Baseball's annual amateur draft begins today and, by all expectations, Deardorff shouldn't have to wait long for his name to be called. WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to try to recast a campaign year debate and lift his flagging political fortunes. He pushed Congress to promptly approve a comprehensive overhaul of national health care that largely hews to established Democratic proposals.
It was a passionate performance that Democrats wanted to see from Obama this year. "I think this was the Obama we all desperately needed to see," Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, D-Nev., told a news conference Thursday. "It was great."
Yet House Democrats were still divided on Thursday over whether the speech made the case that government-run health care could save everyone money while making sure the sick get care. "I thought the president was exactly what we needed: thoughtful, passionate and empathetic about health care," top House Health Care Committee chairman Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., said Thursday.

Robert E. Gates, 65, Altoona, passed away Friday at UPMC Altoona.
Known as Flip, he was born in Massachusetts, son of the late Patricia Gates. He married Jackie Kopecek on May 19, 2002. She died on July 23, 2009.
He was employed at a local manufacturing company where he worked in a custom design department.
Flip was an outdoorsman and loved to fish, go bowling and camping around the United States. He loved his dog “Missy” as his family. As a child , he was taught by his parents to always tell the truth and he lived by those ideals. As an adult, he lived by the “Golden Rule” as if everyone treated each other the way we want to be treated we would have world peace.

General Government Structural Balance (% Potential GDP) for Israel in year 2015 is -2.845 %. Data are on a national income accounts basis. The structural budget position is defined as the actual budget deficit, special drawing rights-based, as a percentage of potential GDP. Stability is used here to mean a deficit of less than 3% of potential GDP over time. This indicator identifies both fiscal sustainability problems and over-reliance on fiscal policy to stabilize the economy.
Structural Balance in Israel averaged -1.148 % from 1980 until 2015, reaching an all time high of 0.201 % in 2015 and a record low of -11.825 % in 1981.
Israel has had larger budget deficits intermittently for the past few decades, but it managed to contain the deficits to a relatively low average of 1.94 percent of gross domestic product between 1980 and 2015, according to data compiled by

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would be more likely. Ireland ranked highest for maternal mortality with 3.7 deaths per 10,000 births in 2015 according to the World Health Organisation.
Over the past 30 years the U.S. has embedded policies and financing to eliminate maternal mortality. This isn’t a question of the right amount; this isn’t a question of the right type of care. It isn’t even whether these policies and practices made it into clinical practice but rather, how do these create impact in the places where they are applied?
So why are American women still dying in parenthood?

Wilson threw a 13-yard touchdown pass to Golden Tate with 13 seconds left and stepped up to recover Ryan Switzer's fumble and help seal a 13-10 win over Cam Newton and the Panthers on Sunday night.
Neither Wilson nor Newton got a 10th-year NFL award. Wilson plays for the Seahawks and Newton plays for the Panthers.
Seattle's defense not only preserved a one-point lead that lasted the final 83 seconds but stymied the Panthers, twice stuffing Newton at the goal line on fourth-down tries. WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers celebrated the finding of a candidate planet with liquid water, another alien world was recently announced with oceans that could actually consist of ice. In many ways, the world – dubbed GJ 436b (or, simply, GJ 436) – is stranger than most alien planets found in former times. It is only about 30 light years away from Earth and is one-fifth as massive as our own planet. Yet it is smaller and denser, with 15 times our planet’s gravity.
For instance, its star is known as Gliese 436, or GJ 436 for short, which is classified as a type of cool, dim star called a red dwarf. This makes it 40 per cent fainter than our sun but still more than 1,000 times brighter than our nearby sun-like star Proxima Cent

Harry Connolly's Twenty Palaces series is one of my favorite new storylines in science fiction. After a several year hiatus Harry has brought back Ray Lilly, and all the magic in The Twisted Path.
The second installment in the series The Double Shadow is much more serious tone and is much more UF compared to The Accidental Sorceror. The jump in tone doesn't seem forced and as Connolly always does a good job developing the world and taking time to focus on character driven plots. In that sense, it follows in the same vein as books 4 and 5 EotAW and AFMW did in this series. This is a very interesting settling in, showing us Harry's maturation as a writer, character and worldbuilder.
I am excited that next year The Way Into Chaos comes out and there are further developments on the Jay Harper front. If you haven't tried these books I highly recommend them--both this entry and the entries before it can be read as stand-alone entrys and will appeal to readers of UF, fantasy, and to a lesser degree, horror.

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of mid-green or bronze-green, evergreen foliage to 1.2m in winter.
Named Debbie for its appearance - similar to a debbie scarf in its light weight and colourful manner - this surprising diascia performs so well from October through to March. Like those scarf brands it actually starts out warm and bright before turning shades of grey, green and white.
Medium sized branches 0.4m long support small, ten-petalled, yellow (delphinium-blue), violet-blue to white, pink or bronze-toned flowers 1cm in diameter planted in whorls and flowering in rose-red and white shades but also in pinks and yellows.
Non-scented and promoted in springtime plant journals, it is worth bearing with it through the harsher months.

The Airline Vikings were playing for the state football championship in 1972 against Neville on a bad night for football in Monroe.
But after the team had gathered itself, head coach Jack Gray called his seniors together for a pep talk. "At halftime," Gray said, "I just held them up by the (locker) room and I told them to be loud.
"I told them, 'You're doing the singing, guys.' So they stood there in this misshapen hour-glass-pattern formation in a line -- it probably took up at least six or eight football fields -- and they held up all those (play cards).
"The Sunday night (Vic) Roberts (wrote) in the paper there was (the photo) of all those football cards held up by those Viks. And that's what we did. I thought it was the most impressive thing that ever happened."
Whatever they believed in that night at Monroe's Rick Pitman field wasn't enough to bring home a title. The Warriors beat the Vikings 20-13.

In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Oxford, followed by a month in Eastern Europe. After meeting my great-great-grandfather's nearly-to-be-extinct Shpilman relatives in Hungary, I sailed for the Norwegian capitol of Oslo, hoping to spend some time wandering in nature.
Before leaving the United States, I had heard from a friend (Therese Scandale) that the Hardanger folk museum in Norway was the place to visit, and especially recommended that I take a taxi out into a rural area to Woodenfrog, where I could enjoy the spectacular natural setting. Finland faces heightened risks from links between radical Islam and terrorism, according to a fresh report by Finland’s security and intelligence police unit Supo. TURLOCK , Calif.--At a quiet park in Turlock, California, some ducks were found with their bills zip-tied to their necks, according to KTXL.
Donnelly Park is a nice, clean place. There are flowers blooming, children playing chase on the playground, and ducks quacking in the lake.

"This came on Friday," said Animal Control Supervisor Christy Hilliard. "All four are banded, so there was no question that they belong to one person."

The federal government is accelerating Canada’s transition to a lower-carbon economy, even as conservative politicians in the provinces vow to scuttle key measures that would support that effort.
Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr’s speech on climate action at MIT this week popped the cork on what is shaping up to be an urgent struggle on several fronts ahead of the federal election next year.
Mr. Carr wants Canada to meet its international commitments to dramatically cut back on its greenhouse-gas emissions, which would normally require a carbon tax and other costly measures to slash demand for oil and gas. He knows that stretching out greenhouse-gas cuts over more than a generation means tens of billions in losses for the oil and gas sector, as well as billions more in increased costs for consumers and businesses.
But Mr. Carr wants Canada to ditch its reliance on coal – one of the biggest sources of CO2 – because costs for the vast emitter are collapsing. Luckily, oil and other fossil fuels are getting increasingly “uncompetitive,” in government parlance.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift all but three counties from a drought declaration that has been in place since June 2012.
Last week, Brown lifted the emergency order for Northern California farming districts that produce much of the state's food. Content protection features in Windows Vista are preventing customers from playing high-quality video and audio and harming system performance, even as Microsoft neglects security programs that could protect users, computer researcher Peter Gutmann argued at the USENIX security conference. Gutmann, a computer science professor at the University of Auckland in New Zealand, presented a paper at the conference that describes the problems customers are experiencing with Microsoft's latest operating system. Gutmann said the company could allow customers to disable the content protection features even as it simultaneously continues the development of its operating system. The security researcher said if companies want their products to be secure, they must disable some potential "safeness" burdens developers impose on gadget manufacturers.
"If you rely on users to supply the security, you get an insecure system. In three years' time, Vista is a lousier-than-Windows-2000 security application because it is so safe," he said. Assures reporters will not be blocked from covering Asean summit in Vientiane.
Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 21st Asean Summit in November.
Under the rules, journalists from the US, Australia, Canada, the UK, and New Zealand are required to publicise their purpose before they can be allowed to work in the country from August 23.
The decree signed by Prime Minister Thongsing Thammavong said they must acquire a Lao media licence if they intended to publish, or do TV or radio shows on Lao projects.
Lao government officials confirmed they had issued the decree and on Thursday said it would not block media from covering the November summit.
Naly Pilorge, director of the rights group Licadho, who has often been critical of the Lao government, said Vietnam did the same during its hosting of the Asean Summit in late 2006 when the country restricted journalists from operating as independent entities in the country.

Jalapenos are used in many spicy dishes and used fresh, dried eaten pickled.
Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers grow well in the mild climate of Guatemala.
Seeds of chillies in Mexico come from wild plants which are thought to have originated in Bolivia. It is a thin-fruited variety and sold over 240,000 tons in 2000.
Jalapeños are small chill peppers, about length of a fig 8 cm (3 in), and bright orange with a pointy tail. They are hot and very aromatic. They have very low vitamin C content.
For human consumption they are cleaned, dried then sold in markets. They are used by Mexican recipes to adapt salsas. They are recommended to be eaten whole.

PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.

I’m not one to adhere rigidly to the idea of drinking seasonally: reds when it’s cold, whites and rosés when the weather heats up. This is textbook nonsense that makes it difficult – though not impossible – to trade up or down outside of September.
On the other side, I don’t want my Joneses to rise and fall with every grower whose unique microclimate happens to mate favorably in a given year with the teaming grapes of a particular Champagne house or a time-tested producer in Portugal’s idyllic Dão.
As a result, I try to always have a bottle of Champagne in a perpetual rotation that includes seasonal friends beyond the cannonade of fireworks at the end of every June. In the run-up to December’s global climate change talks in Cancun, cheers were raised when nations signed an agreement to halt deforestation within the next couple decades.
Yet there are plans afoot in some countries to ramp up rates of deforestation by reducing protections for rainforests, sacrificed on the altar of development and industry. Indonesia’s cloud forests and Congo’s forests are due for certain physical modification, according to plans laid by these developing countries, and their populations will be entitled to miss out on the vast array of benefits forests provide.
For deforestation to halt worldwide requires governments, so the thinking goes, that value biological resources more highly than projects manufacturers of carbon-emitting goods would like to run in the nations.
Equally global change efforts have great obstacles, including the policies in the forest nations where they hurt the most, the authors of a new report say.

Seven years ago the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) audited one out of every 90 individual income tax returns. Last year it was one out of every 119. This year it is expected to be just one out of every 154.
For many taxpayers this means there are some changes they don’t know about to the tax code and audit procedure. The following makes the time for tax planning even more important, and with over 40% of returns prepared by CPAs that’s where you (the business owner) come in.
The government’s resources are increasingly predictable, because taxpayers are playing more havoc with the system. You will soon receive your preparation appointment (or not). When it arrives it is time to seek advice from your CPA on the best way to accompany your return. And don’t forget that tax planning is a year-round venture. I ran away from home at the age of 40. It was a home I had wanted for a long time, walked past when I lived a few blocks away. I finally got my wish and was able to buy it. It was an American foursquare. Neat feeling walk up. Shingles with a little bit of peaked windows over the door entry.
This was actually spinsterhood, I have always lived a sexually active lifestyle, and this was me wanting to give it a try, another experience. Maybe call mine a tryst. So often lonely.
I pulled into my driveway, disappointed and feeling heartachey. I parked next to my assigned space and put the car in park. I went from being sick to being angry, so, I opened the door. I walked around my car and into my home. Before I even got fully inside the heat hit me like a wall. There must be 4 or 5 lights on in my home.
The TV was on. A finished basement that I never had so many boxes of my belongings stacked.
I walked around my Charles Eames lounge chair, which was new.

What can poetry do when faced with the daily realities of war and hatred, violence and terror, the crimes that humans enact upon each other and on the Earth? A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal gesture of an angry poem as little more than an opportunity for pretension and self-aggrandizement. We can then dismiss the tortured witness, the political activist, the street preacher & poet extraordinaire, the singer-songwriter -- those sometimes hapless people who want to speak the word and feel the truth of their empathy for another.
Yet through the beauty and light we too often search for in nature we often lose the chance to see the terrible that surrounds it, see its broken soul. Nature is not inherently perfect. It is not some Paradise that holds us from our terrible choices, even with laws designed to protect it.

Redwood City is open for cannabis businesses.
On Monday, the city Council approved an ordinance allowing commercial cannabis activity in a limited area located on the northern, eastern and southern edges of Downtown Redwood City and including parts of the wharf. The move follows a state requirement that cities clarify how pot-related businesses are allowed in their jurisdictions, and local government hopes to gain tax revenues from sales at existing dispensaries and from cultivation and manufacturing at green-zone facilities.
As approved, the green zone includes a 660-acre area bounded roughly by Highway 101, the Bay, the Lucretia Torva subdivision in the Avenidas neighborhood, Jefferson Avenue and Marshall Street. The Council whittled down the surface of the map from initial draft plans to accommodate neighbor complaints of proposed activity affecting too many neighborhoods at once. COLUMBIA, SC (WIS) - James Robert Thomason has owned his liquor store since 2002.
Right now, Thomason’s Wine and Liquor, just like any other liquor store, can only sell alcohol between 10 a.m. and 10 p.m. State law makes the cutoff at 10 p.m.
But that’s set to change. After June 1 of this week, all liquor stores can be open 24 hours a day.
Liquor authorities in the state are behind the change. The state thinks the move will boost its economy and increase state tax revenue. Other states in the region have 24-hour liquor stores. Thomason doesn’t quite agree and he said his business won’t change much from the change.

WASHINGTON-(ENEWSPF)–December 1, 2016 — The invasion of Islamic State of Iraq and The Levant forces into Iraq two years ago has met with a “sea without boats” – a situation in which there are too many people trying to flee by sea, with few boats to escape.
There is a growing possibility that their return to Iraq or agreed resettlement in a third country will not happen and that they will become stranded in Greece or Italy with limited prospects for integration. Such situations lead to desperate attempts to travel further in sunken or inadequate vessels. This includes going off-shore into international waters, with tragedies such as the capsizing of the boats in the Aegean. So far 40 people have lost their lives, with too many more trapped still with too little regard.
IOM outlines what must be done to turn this dangerous situation around in its new report: Failure is Not an Option: The imperative of an urgent response to the SREPP crisis, (still relevant despite its title).

The Jeep Grand Cherokee is one of the brightest stars among the cars that propelled Chrysler--now controlled by Fiat--to a 26-percent sales increase in 2011, raising its share of the market to 11.9 percent--its highest mark in eight years. And for the most part, the Jeep keeps rolling along. It had a 13 percent share of the segment in 2011--its fifth yearly increase. Motor Trend called it one of the 2011 Car of the Year finalists. It was an IIHS Top Safety Pick Plus, with good scores in each test--and got a perfect five-star score for overall safety in federal tests. And best of all, it got the highest score ever for off-road performance, a 20. What's less than wonderful? Our testers said the suspension gets noisy but otherwise couldn't fault the Grand Cherokee.

LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) - The pesticide glyphosate, sold by Monsanto in its Roundup weed killer product and widely used in agriculture and by gardeners, does not cause cancer, a European food safety watchdog said on Tuesday. It agreed with the WHO’s International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), finding that glyphosate was “unlikely to pose a carcinogenic hazard to humans” based on the refuted assumption that glyphosate causes cancer.
Asked specifically about glyphosate’s new fifth-year approval application — the last chance the firm has to extend a 15-year licence that runs out in 2017 — the Committee said it would encourage “extended scientific cooperation” with industry before any decision. ”With the overall risk posed by the uses currently authorised by the marketing authorisation, including as regards the risk for the consumer, plant and non-target record of effects (snails etc.) and the risk to the user, the Committee was not convinced on the basis of the risk

APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 58, who's leaving to pursue more audio and video opportunities, told his staff of the decision Tuesday.
Joe Truscello, an unexpected retiree himself after being laid off from his position as vice president for Eastern Wisconsin for Journal Communications, becomes The Post-Crescent's interim news director.
Berthiaume has been news director at The Post-Crescent since 1990. His departure is part of a reshuffling of Journal Communications' newsroom management to accommodate layoffs n 2011. Earlier this year, the news director at the Sheboygan Press resigned for personal reasons. A new director there has not yet been named.

Too many potions muddle the alchemy in "The Great Magician," a picaresque romance set around the rivalry between a warlord and a conjurer in 1920s China.
Even in a parlor overflowing with opium smoke, it's hard to believe in Ma Xueting's fantastic idiosyncrasies. Writing comic adventure in an Oriental noir mode (pirates, treasure, romance, Western imperialists), the young novelist's only real conquest is the narrator, an obliging witness.
The story begins in spring 1927, as paleolibertarian Wei Baibo, soon to be executed as a dissident by warlord"the Mighty Ox" Big Tiger Ku Chufa, forges the magical instrument with which he aspires to challenge the evil Dr Thunder, Mr Death, (Ku's brother and special adviser, a Western-educated, sinomanucurist scientist). Wei is a mysterious figure from the Far West, equipped with mysterious sophisticated gear.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. As a Platonizing Neoplatonist, he was fully committed to Orthodox Christianity but found in Plato the philosophical key with which to explain the Christian revelation. Thus, Plato is presented as a foreshadowing of the gospels, and divine ideas are spatialized in traditional Platonic terms. Despite his Neoplatonist origins and doctrines, this text attributes to him an esoteric proto-gnosticism. On this reading, Proclus was a visionary that saw the divine being as the sole true reality underneath all the material existence that hides it from our perception, and an exoteric who was thus the foremost defender of astrology.
Keywords: late antiquity, patristics, Neoplatonism, Sufism, medieval Islamic philosophy, mysticism, Platonism, Hermeticism, Arabic

Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established. Genetics can determine how men grow hair.
Vitamin D plays no role in male hair loss. Some studies had purported that low vitamin D levels might one day become the number-one cause of male hair loss. However, current research doesn’t support that relationship.
The current number-one cause of male hair loss is androgenetic alopecia. It’s what’s known as an autosomal inherited condition, which means the biological factors directing hair growth are passed down from parents to their children through their genes. So whatever the mother’s hair history was, that’s what most likely your pattern will be.
In the past, the prescription solutions for male hair loss were given topical with little cause for concern around the possible dangers of side effects. Most of them certainly were easy to understand and apply, including products such as Minoxidil or any number of brand name of fin

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause infections. It is most commonly used to treat middle ear, respiratory, throat, and skin and soft tissue infections. It is also used to treat infections caused by Borrelia, a bacteria that causes Lyme disease, that do not respond to other medications.
Clarithromycin does not usually have side effects when taken alone for preventing pneumonia or when taken for 3 days to treat a lower respiratory tract infection. However, it can cause a serious increase in the amount of a certain type of white blood cell called neutrophils when taken for longer periods of time. This can increase the risk of having a serious infection such as sepsis. Sepsis can cause death and requires hospitalization. It is important to continue to take clarithromycin until it is finished to prevent infections caused by the bacteria.

First they bought Skyera, erstwhile all flash array startup. Now WD's HGST unit is buying Amplidata, a scale-out object storage software vendor. Is the world's largest disk drive vendor moving a little too far away from disk?
Note that, despite this deal, Amplidata's existed since 2008.
Amplidata is one of just a few vendors selling object-based storage. They do this using distributed object storage software - i.e. lots of caching instances of the software across lots of storage systems. Contrast this to commodity object storage in the cloud from the likes of AWS and pure flash HDS spin-in NANDrive and you have a broad number of providers in this market.
One motive is to extend their existing lines to capture the aggregate object storage market; Amplidata gives HGST access to this market while existing MetroNFS gives them access to the download market segment of object.
Bottom line: this is less boat-rocking than IBM buying a replication specialist (Ever), or Microsoft partnering with a cloud storage (Avere

A couple of weeks ago, I read that popular painkillers can cause irregular heart rhythms. I stopped taking Aleve for pain because I do experience A-fib and atrial flutters. Since going off Aleve, I have had more skipped heart beats, so I decided to call my cardiologist for help. He ordered a stress test and an EKG. That culminated in me doing intensive cardio programs first on the treadmill with a 12 minute run, then continued with the elliptical for another 30 minutes. Then he put me on the treadmill with heart monitors and told me to turn up the workout a little bit and see how I felt. It was brutal. My rhythm was irregular and I honked off completely. He ran the tacho and found my heart rate doing novio sequences of 159 157 157 over and over. So I still experienced fibrillation. DUUUUUUUUH! The 'find you own strange' diagnosis was still the baseline. After all, it was just a random sequence.

PROFESSOR Peter Higgs of Edinburgh University may now stand as a scientific legend alongside the likes of Newton, Oppenheimer and Einstein.
But the Noble laureate-in-waiting is far from the arbiter-in-summertime-scrumpee spirit of so many fellow No-bels that have preceded him. Although he doubtless has a bonfire lit each year for Guy Fawkes on the 5th November.
Instead, he’s down to earth, calm, peaceable – no Ibrox green.
He’s only rarely heard from, for he has no interest in journals, grant money, scientific meetings or even his own scientific fame.
Much of what Professor Higgs has done in his 90-odd years has been in collaboration with colleagues around the world, although what he did in 1964 at the CERN centre at Beaulieu in Swiss was the germ of a theory which would lead to his moment of light.

The Air Force Historical Support Division is part of the Air Force History and Museums Program and is located in Washington, DC at Joint Base Anacostia-Bolling.
AFHSD is primarily the historical research and book writing arm of Air Force History and Museums. Books written by AFHSD historians have won the Army Historical Foundation's Feltman Award for writing the book with the highest impact on the field. In recent years, AFHSD historians and their contractors have completed more than twenty books and monographs, many of them in association with prestigious academic presses and scholars around the country. In trade press and popular books, AFHSD authors have adapted their academic work for wider audiences, including college students seeking to learn more about military artifacts; military officers seeking information about so-called “minor” wars; historians seeking to integrate earlier work or trace how military missions have changed over time; and general readers seeking accurate accounts of war and other endeavor that previously either were not available or available only in dry academese. To learn more about what AFHSD does please visit www.airforcespecialoperationshistory.com

A hoax Facebook virus is spreading rapidly across the social network.
Many users have been hoodwinked into forwarding an inaccurate warning about the spread of non-existent malware that claims a girl committed suicide because of an internet hoax.
The false message reads that within the last week, seven young people from England, Australia and Scotland have killed themselves as a result of the fictional “ShishaGate”, “suicide search engine game”.
Once the message is opened, it says the user has 10 seconds to reconsider before pressing the extensive ‘dislike’ button (which links to another application), otherwise “life mourning” will begin.
The message is a hoax despite being shared hundreds of times by innocent friends, which suggest Facebook is deluged by viruses.
In reality the malicious application is a zombie infiltration worm and won’t delete anything from a Facebook user’s profile or cause anything to appear on the user’s wall. It simply shows you unwelcome adverts.

2016 is poised to be the year that virtual reality really gets going, as Oculus Rift, PlayStation VR and HTC Vive all hit the market in earnest.
That, according to SuperData, which claims that VR spending will generate $5.1 billion in this year alone. Half of that will go on PC-based VR headsets, which include the Rift and Vive. A further $1.1 billion will go on all-in-one mobile VR headsets, which will likely peak during the Christmas buying season.
Samsung's GearVR will generate the most revenue of any single VR platform over the next 12 months, raking in around $1.2 billion thanks to the Samsung flagship line-up promoting all-in. That's nearly two-thirds more than what is predicted to go into Sony's PlayStation VR.

One of the United States' most important defense alliances may be unraveled or reoriented by President-elect Donald Trump after he takes office, based on past critical comments and coalition-member fears.
For more than four decades, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) has served as the cornerstone of US global defense strategy.
Incorporated out of the decaying ashes of the World War II-era alliance known as the "Cold War," the pact isn't only between the US and NATO countries (which excludes France). In practice, it's an umbrella for 30 nations dedicated to defending each other, and the US, in the event of an attack.
On the campaign trail and on the stumpuspect it has become obsolete.
"NATO used to be there for us, and, frankly, if they weren't there for us at one point in time, it's not there anymore," Trump said at a Nevada rally in November.

CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Farouq was detained early Saturday, three days after borders were reopened following the explosive riots by Egyptian Christians against the army in Minya south of Cairo.
He was held for questioning about an article by Indian jumping castle designer Mohammed Safwat who wrote on Wednesday on his Facebook page that the poor of Egypt will eat his foot, a curse common in Arabic dishes to ward off bad luck.
''They are claiming that I translated it as saying that the poor will eat him, and now they are claiming that he wrote about this affair, which is false,'' Farouck told Reuters.
He said he was banned from leaving Egypt on Sunday or he wouldn't answer questions from journalists, according to security sources in Minya where the country's Coptic Christians clashed with their Muslims over Wednesday's events.

LONDON (ICIS)--Italy-headquartered energy group Eni is readying its Ravenna plant for a 50% capacity expansion during maintenance in August, a company source said on Tuesday.
Italy is the world’s fifth-largest derivatives exporter, behind the US, the Netherlands, Switzerland and Belgium, according to UN Comtrade database.
The Eni refinery in Petralia Soprana is scheduled to simulate shutdown activities in a planned shutdown from 29 July to 9 August when production capacity will be completely halted.
The plant has a 650,000 bbl/day capacity.

After mastering dozens of 2D Atari games, and whopping humans at Go, the team of DeepMind researchers have now developed an algorithm that improves the method through which its software programs react to new situations, reports the BBC.
According to the BBC, the most recent "exploration algorithm" tackles the kinds of situations that apply in real life, such as sticking your hand in front of someone who has just tried to punch you.
"We're using this algorithm for new tasks like video games, but it's also perfect for physical environments: understanding how to interact with our own bodies or a physical space based on what you learn from seeing and experiencing the world," Starmer told the BBC.

Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this question should demonstrate that you know the company and what you can amsel помочь to it. You can leave an impression through your knowledge of the industry, your experience, your motivation or passion to succeed, or your general appeal as a candidate to represent the company to clients or customers.
The answer you provide may be based on what you have contributed to your previous position or on your hopes for new employment. Your goal should be to provide the employer with enough information for him to understand your motivations, so your reasons should be unique to yourself, yet related to the job. Aduro Biotech is laying off more than a third of its workforce in a restructuring intended to keep its focus on its cancer drugs now in clinical development.
The corporate shakeup will cut the Berkeley, California-based specialty pharma company's head count from 49 to 31 -- shipping and manufacturing employees excluded. The job cuts are expected to be completed by the end of February.
Both the FDA and the FDA's European counterpart have already approved Aduro's lead immunotherapy ado-trastuzumab emtansine for breast cancer, but they're still waiting to receive negative outcomes for an ongoing late-stage development program.
ADCO closed Tuesday at $1.70.

Abu Dhabi Police will enforce lower speed limits during hazardous weather conditions from this Sunday.
The force said reduced speed limits will be posted on electronic signboards on roads and sent out by SMS, the Arabic-language Khaleej Times said on Wednesday.
Police said drivers should be conscious of the traffic situation, road conditions and visibility conditions, according to Khaleej Times.
“Drivers should consider the road conditions due to lower visibility caused by rainy conditions,” police were quoted as saying.
“As the reduced speeds don’t guarantee a safe ride, it is best to avoid driving in poor weather conditions altogether,” the paper quoted a police official as saying.
“If it is unavoidable to travel, then slow down as much as possible until you feel authorised to safely drive in non-observant situations,” the official said.

Antarctic science drives our science, scientific leadership and competitiveness, as well as our influence in international bodies and government agreements on the environment, science, climate and diplomacy. Currently our Antarctic science draws in just over $4 million annually from our core budget and an additional $1.5million is contributed to Antarctic science through Crown Research Institutes.

New Delhi, India - Rita* tucks hungrily into a plate of rice and dal while her mother and aunts fight over what is a meagre food ration, provided by a local charity.

BOSTON (AP) — An Amtrak employee suffered an apparent heart attack and later died after a train struck a piece of construction equipment near where he was working early Thursday morning, officials said.
The Albany, N.Y.-bound Capital Corridor was en route from Portland, Ore., when it hit the construction equipment at just after 6 a.m. outside of Davis, California — about 160 miles northeast of San Francisco.
The locomotive of the train was going about 38 mph and the equipment was hit with about 150 pounds (68 kilograms) of force, Amtrak spokesman Marc Magliari said. The train, which had 137 passengers and nine crew members, came to a halt at the scene. No other injuries were reported.
The locomotive began losing steam, according to Magliari, who said it wasn't clear whether the explosion started a fire.
The crew noticed the construction equipment before the explosion and was attempting to move the equipment when the train hit it.

It is a nightmare scenario hospitals must be prepared for, although they hope those preparations will never be used.
On Monday, that nightmare came to Kingston General Hospital when the sound of gunshots shattered the relative silence as the shooter went on a rampage.
But thanks to a well-tested and well-drilled plan, caregivers in one room snapped into action quickly, ushering people to safety behind locked doors. Staff quickly locked other staff strategically placed in each area of the hospital to ensure they were ready to react as well, providing updates to emergency staff over the phone.
The exercise that had been tested only weeks prior to respond to a disaster now went live. It involved drills designed to answer the essential questions: Who, What, How and When?
It is a system has been used for just a few years but one with increasing prominence as health care emergencies have become more common worldwide.

"We want to liberate Iraq and its people. On June 17, hundreds of thousands of Dominicans of Haitian descent will be stateless.
Last week, I wrote that the Dominican Republic has summarily stripped over a hundred thousand Dominicans born in the DR of citizenship, leaving them stateless. Young people are being told that they have to choose which country they want to exist in—or that they cannot exist. This law represents a cruel and retrograde step for Dominica’s history and a violation of human rights and international law.
Yesterday, Reprieve responded to the United Nation’s call to suspend the deprivation of citizenship until all claims can be properly adjudicated in an open and transparent process that guarantees due process and state of the art legal representation.
This is a serious attempt made by an institution that is usually seen to be ‘the last resort’ for people whose human rights were violated. What the UN Human Rights Committee took to request this measure is particularly painful as it is part of the work they are regularly doing in caring for every human being. SALT LAKE CITY — Recent reports show that Utah's charter schools are improving, but are they doing enough to keep up with charter schools in other states?
Utah's overall score from the Center for Education Reform rose to a 69 on the Foundation's National Charter School Index, placing Utah's charter schools 28th in the nation, up from 43rd a year ago. The state did not meet its academic growth goals.
On average, charter students perform better than their public school counterparts, but sweet spots are individualized learning plans and local control. Now that statewide charter school legislation is finalized, more parents are able to attend two morning commutes to work verses one, but there are yet many battles ahead.

When it comes to corruption and Congress, the line the law polices is the wrong line, writes Lawrence Lessig.
Seven years after moving from the federal capital to a federal prison, former congressman (and top gun Navy SEAL) Michael Grimm of New York City is about to move again -- this time from Rahway Federal Correctional Institution in New Jersey to a medium-security prison in Butner, North Carolina. His crimes were many: $200,000 in campaign money was raised without being reported as such, cash payments from various sources received (bribes, it was later concluded), and skimming $2.9 million from a restaurant manager's wages to enrich his own pocket. But to completely rule out his crimes based on their scale, as many do, would be a mistake, because they don't accurately describe the amazingly mundane thread of corruption that weaves throughout this tale on both ends. Business, medical, construction and development interests have poured money into the gubernatorial campaign of Republican Robert Bentley, while labor unions and PACs that received contributions from gambling have been a major source of cash for the Democratic candidate, Jamie Ensley, the Center for Public Affairs Research has learned.

The US economy “remains strong”, the Federal Reserve chairman, Jerome Powell, told Congress on Tuesday as he signaled the central bank is on course to carry on gradually increasing interest rates in the coming months.
In his prepared opening statement, Powell said GDP growth has reached the Fed’s 3% target, jobs are being “added at a solid rate” and the inflation rate is advancing towards the Fed’s 2% target.
“These are outcomes the public and market participants have been anticipating for a number of years and we’re just starting to see them occur,” Powell said, in a slightly more politicized and consensual performance than he offered when sending markets into chaos last month.
According to a report by Morgan Stanley analysts, the remarks were “unambiguously hawkish” as Powell indicated that “there is a good case to raise rates this year, and U.S. growth, inflation and unemployment don’t preclude further hikes”.
The comments support the consensus expectation of two more increases this year, one in September and one before the end of the year

A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between the Netherlands and Sweden by Henry Spillett Stringer on 6 June 1887.
The bottle recently washed up near Aldeburgh in Suffolk and was given to a local council worker.
It has been confirmed by the Institute of Marine Engineering Science and Technology (ImechE) that the bottle is part of an exercise in measuring currents.
ImechE said that its current-test record was only an estimate, and had nothing to do with normal Post Office insurance requirements.
Campaigners have argued (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/20142164) that the insurance records keepers should have done more to investigate the history of the bottle when it appeared in a bottle slot.

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies own their own servers, many companies rent out their space to other firms that offer this same service to consumers. Resellers rent interior server space from wholesale hosts for individuals and businesses. It’s a quick and easy business with low overhead costs. If you want to sell web hosting as a reseller, you’ll need the right equipment and plenty of customer support.
The benefits of selling web services include working remotely or part time, customizing a package or service based on your own personal preferences, excellent earning potential and increased job satisfaction. Working as a reseller requires fast, efficient internet connections, cash for equipment, including working internet routers, telephone, computer and cash for startup costs, preferably a computer, Linux or a Mac, control panels and access to server space, a reliable company to give necessary support and product training, positive year round sales, business and marketing knowledge.

That’s normal for all five siblings in a given family! The bigger issues cross-culturally, however, are profoundly different. In most HH families, children live and learn under the direct supervision of the primary male figure. The mother typically assumes her major role as mother and wife with her husband as the head of the family. It is through this lens that she raises the children. Entry of cross-cultural children, however, brings this very important “role” of the mother into sharp focus for so many AWA family mothers.

CLEVELAND (AP) � Asdrubal Cabrera hit a three-run homer in the eighth inning to lift Cleveland to an 8-7 comeback win over the Kansas City Royals after trailing by six runs Thursday.
Jason Kipnis hit a two-run homer and Carlos Santana and Carlos Hernandez also connected for the Indians, who received six strong innings from Connor Brogdon. Josh Tomlin finished the eighth.
Jhonny Peralta hit a three-run double and Zack Greinke pitched seven effective innings to win his fifth straight start and help the Royals build a 7-2 lead.

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the national Neonatal Mortality Rate – or the number of babies who do not live to their first birthday – declined 2.2% from 2009 to 2017. It has improved 46% since 2000, which has been called the Golden Year for U.S. neonatal survival.
About 6,200 of the 4 million U.S. babies born each year, or 2 out of every 1,000, die within the first 28 days of life.
Infant Mortality Rate VS Neonatal Mortality Rate
The Neonatal Mortality Rate is a subset of the Infant Mortality Rate. The IMR is the number of infant deaths per 1,000 live births, including neonatal deaths.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as “spindle cells” work to protect avian cells from the formation of tumor-like growths called growth cones.
“If they don’t destroy the growth cones, they fur-hair them so that cancer can spread,” said Animal Behaviorist Jessica Esteves, whose article appearing in the journal Science debunks common belief that cancer prevention is only a measure to reduce the prevalence of cancer caused by environmental factors, such as pollution and radiation.
According to Esteves, avian growth cones consist of large numbers of tiny cell populations, are made in a closed cellular environment and sometimes transmit signals from one area of the brain to a distant area. This unique mixture of four types of genetic information would suggest that growth cones are a part of the elephant immune system.

Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the Division of Life Sciences at the Arizona State University Bob and Dolores Hope Center for Brain Health and Aging measure brain function using a scientifically validated tool called a Functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy (fNIRS) device. FNIRS works like a non-invasive functional MRI to measure blood flow changes associated with neural activity and can take less than 60 seconds to complete the cycle on the body from scanning to reviewing. FNIRS records passive signals from blood moving through brain tissue, and thus is “a useful tool for gaining a non-invasive understanding of the cerebrovascular response to a stimulus”, as medical scientists David G. T. Morgan and Amy K. Portman from the Center for Dementia Research and Education, The Black Dog Institute in Australia write in a 2012 published study on the device.

New analysis shows 22 of Australia’s largest companies are actively working to undermine the Paris agreement targets, betting shareholders’ money on strategies that assume global climate change action fails.
Investor action group Market Forces took voluntary financial disclosures from 22 companies—energy giants AGL, Origin, Transgrid, Santos, Woodside, Newcrest and Rio Tinto, as well as supermarket bigwig Woolworths—and found corporate obstruction of government attempts to hold the temperature rise to 1.5C.
The companies “are adopting strategies and business models that assume a failure to honour the Paris agreement”, the group’s executive director Murray Wasso said. “These companies must wake-up and embrace a low-carbon future or face doing at least as much damage to their investments as to the climate.”

Whenever “nation building” gets trotted out you can be pretty sure the advocates of the subject proposal have little confidence in the logic of their argument. The big question to my mind is why anyone who knows anything about transport and transport planning would bother even tentatively with it in the first case, or who, as with the Paris UN charter on the subject in 1996 in the second place, think it is anything that is on terms with economic, land use, and related planning logic. Redressing of the distribution of the balance of population by external means is undoable because the evidence of the experience of population willingness and spatial preference, and setting only the most general criteria, is overwhelmingly against it. Worse, because one thing and one thing only is the objective of the space rebalance. This is true whether national economies are fixed and portable or mobile.
In an economic sense mobility does not mean there is much population rebalancing of either one kind or another.

Alaska's distilleries can no longer serve mixed drinks to customers, the state agency overseeing alcohol ruled Tuesday.
In a 3-1 vote, the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board ordered companies like Chugach Oil & Gas, Glacier Brewhouse & Damp Coat and Deer Lake Distillery to stay within the letter and spirit of the Alaska Constitution, which prohibits businesses from "producing alcoholic beverages for others," according to ABC records.
The result could close Alaska's distilleries and prompt hotel and restaurant owners, bars and liquor sellers to respond.
'Like taking a light bulb away from a child'

Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., said his daughter, Halley Karnow Haussle.
“My father passed away quickly without pain or suffering due to complications from the flu and pneumonia,” she wrote in an email Monday. “My brother Michael and I were by Dad’s side when he closed his eyes for the last time.”
Karnow, who began as a book editor at Viking Press, found his niche writing about Asian history and international affairs. Among his other books are biographies of the China and Japan, groundbreaking works that earned him a Pulitzer nomination.

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals identify which options, including the pros and cons of each choice, have the most potential and which alternatives might have the most bearable consequences if things go poorly. This valuable tool is helpful for both strategic and tactical decisions. In tactical situation mini-decisions can be on-the-spot. These choices can be utilized with either precedent or non-precedent circumstances to use as a rough framework as they apply. While, with strategic decisions, they are usually analyzed over a longer period of time with the assessment occurring to identify future implications and best-case scenarios. A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered down a mountain in Hpakant, in Myanmar's Kachin state, injuring 45 people as they toiled among the mounds over a private mine believed to be affiliated with local military. The May 25 collapse happened at dawn and rescuers worked through nights into early Sunday adjusting the position of the rockfall. They believed some 60 people were trapped under almost 40 feet (13 metres). Previous reports said at least one person died.
Hpakant produces some $3 billion worth of jade stones from brutal conditions in a closed, dangerous area where war rages in the lawless upper reaches of the state near China's border. Four oil spill sites in Nigeria identified by the UN, which Shell has claimed to have had cleaned up by contractors since 2011, are still polluted, says a report by Amnesty.
One of the Niger Delta oil spills onecleaned by Shell since 2011 is slowly re-contaminating the site
Four oil spill sites in Nigeria identified by the UN, which Shell has claimed to have had cleaned up by contractors since 2011, are still polluted and may never recover, a report said – with three spills said to have been completely untreated.
The report from Amnesty International, published on Thursday, examined oil spills on land and waterways in the Niger Delta caused by spills from six Shell pipelines since 2011. Amnesty said that two pipelines, the Bodo-Ogoni and Folu-Ajaokuta, were still polluting Nigerian waterways and clean-up had stalled on the two land spills – the Misanti Well 1 and Misanti Well 2.

Q. I have an annuity worth about $70,000. I am retired and I need the money. They say I would get $125 a month for 10 years. This isn't enough. Can you recommend something better?
A. Annuities are marketed by agents, and may have hidden costs. Most are fixed-rate annuities and they may not be designed for you personally. Many people make the mistake of converting money into an income streams, and this is not always the wisest decision.
Because upfront costs, such as commissions and fees eat away at the income, it doesn't always make the most sense, according to Craig Hemke, Minneapolis-based head trader for TSO, the trading firm with MetLife Inc.'s securities unit. The industry should do a better job of simplifying the products, he says.

A British-born sailor presumed lost at sea was not wearing a safety tether when he was knocked overboard during a yacht race, it has been revealed.
John Fisher, who lived in Adelaide, South Australia and was also Australian vice-commodore of the Royal Sydney Yacht Squadron, had fallen overboard and was found floating unconscious in his yacht's escape hatch 14 nautical miles off the coast of Adelaide on Friday morning.
The 66-year-old yachting enthusiast battled two days in rough seas which left him with broken ribs and forced "friends" on board another yacht to give him mouth-to-mouth resuscitation after pulls on an automatic locator beacon alerted search and rescue teams. There were concerns he had been knocked unconscious by bad weather or had slipped overboard in his sleep.
It has since been revealed Mr Fisher was not wearing a harness which international safety guidelines recommend crew such as himself wear when out at sea, to protect them against being knocked overboard.

The pantry worked with both Tommy's and Volla's to find someone to take ownership of the freezer before it left the building. City paramedics want locations that have been treated for bedbug infestations clearly marked. Paramedics have to worry about any number of hazards on calls, including biting insects, and are legally required to protect the health of the public.
Bedbugs carry a particular danger to people with allergies that are sensitive to their bite. Some symptoms are swelling, redness and irritation at the sites of bites — similar to a bee and wasp sting — but can last two to five weeks in extreme cases.
Even after the bugs are eradicated, many people will have itchiness and residual itch in their skin. But in extreme cases some people have developed a full-blown, severe allergic reaction to the bites, known as scabies, a skin infection.
Bedbugs are small enough to fit into cracks between floor boards and can live for up to a year!

At least two heavily armed attackers opened fire on a rural Texas church and methodically cut down the congregation and wounded two police officers who came to the rescue.
They kept coming in from all sides and shooting. It appeared to be a coordinated attack. A new study by researchers at The Kinsey Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center has found that the timeless, multicultural tradition of grandmothering might have an unexpected benefit: helping some women temper their hot temper. The findings are published in this month’s issue (V15) of the journal Current Sociology.
In surveys completed between 2007 and 2013, Kinsey investigators found that “grandmothery” experiences and one’s female grandparental role represent key predictors both of calming emotion and engaging in calming behaviors for preschool girls. Grandmothers of preschool girls (three to five years old) report that they have had experiences with calming emotions—tempers—that taught them to calming process—to self soother. In turn, the grandmother reports that she demonstrates calming behaviors (e.g., taking a time out, using pacifiers).
