Stinger.next is the second large effort Hortonworks has spearheaded in order to improve the performance of Hive. The company recently completed its goals for the initial Stinger project, on which it began work in 2011. The company is now focusing on the improvements it made while maintaining efficiency and performance.
Historically Hive has had more of a focus on accuracy over performance. But in today’s often-connected world of applications and information, the greater importance is performance, because if consuming a lot of information is taking too much time, then users will move to more efficient platforms and the computational environment of Apache Hadoop becomes less valuable, says Humphrey.
Hortonworks’ Stinger.next effort takes the improved performance of Hortworks’ Stinger recommendation and speeds them out to community and enterprise users in order to accelerate their integration and testing.

Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given -- just another part of the franchise dollars committed to the maintenance fees. Those with less financial muscle and legacy ERP systems have fewer options.
Business process applications such as SAPs "MySAP Business Solutions" are out of the affordability picture for most small and midsize businesses. They may have effective Web CRM, e-mail retailing and financial apps, but they're topped by inadequate supply chain, manufacturing and manufacturing planning systems -- none of which can provide the specialized tools needed for collaboration between a business and its suppliers, customers and vendors.
Larger businesses use commercial E-commerce to collaborate internally and externally. But COO Eric Van Bedeven at Scene4 confirmed that open source provides the best hopes for ERP involving collaboration with suppliers and other parties in the extended enterprise.

Former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, musician Bob Dylan and astronaut John Glenn were among a select group of 13 Americans named by President Obama Thursday as the latest recipients of the nation's highest civilian honor, the Presidential Medal of Freedom.
Obama awarded two present: one to Glenn, the first American to orbit earth, the other to Dylan, the quintessential American musician who at 66 made his long-awaited return to rock music after a sevenyear hiatus with his new album "Together Through Life."
Dylan became a staple of soundtracks in film and television, particularly for Martin Scorsese, Paul Simon and Bruce Springsteen. The first track on Dylan's latest album is a song called "I Feel a Change Comin' On."
Both will receive the Medal of Freedom at the White House before the end of the year at separate ceremonies.

I knew about the existence of the tent city, of course, but honestly didn’t know that much more than that. But what I have learned about Tent City over the past few months is astonishing.
What is Tent City?
Tent City 3.0 is a collection of tents and tarps on the capitol steps outside the downtown Seattle Public Library. This law was amended in 2008 with the Family and Medical Leave Redesign and Extension Act. The California Family Rights Act (CFRA) is also in place so that employees can have entitlement to family leave under federal or state law. This law, too, has been amended to specifically include certain articles. Sunday will be the 42nd annual Earth Day celebration. Here are six facts you should know to celebrate Earth Day like a scientist knows you should!
This year’s Earth Day is tweaking the perfect storm.
The 20th century best-selling novelist Kurt Vonnegut was born on this day in 1922. The opening line of his 1963 classic Slaughterhouse-Five is memorable: “Billy Pilgrim has come unstuck in time.”
More interestingly, Billy Pilgrim knows one thing that a lot of other humans don’t seem to know but that scientists clearly understand today: The planet is definitely warming, as shown by the entire Earth science community, all year long. Despite a lot of corporate denial funding, the American public generally accepts this understanding.
Global warming is real, Earth Day is regular and Kurt Vonnegut is an American classic. And all of these are a perfect storm

How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you will in their rules. This allows them to identify, initiate, and execute good trades based on the chart. This makes sense, as these rules identify if a trade fits you, it eliminates a large amount of randomness, you don't have to worry if things are going to go bad, and eliminates emotions or false data. This is truly the hard part, and is elementary compared to the post-entry rules for management which are more problematic.
This is done in a variety of ways of course, but they have trouble because humans still get emotional so many times. In manual Forex trading, for example, many trades fail because they change the rules halfway, sometimes a partial trade is unloaded at a loss because a trader decides “if this disqualifies the current trade I should exit, well then it must be good..?” This is tough on the mind because humans like to be right, and we changed

TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran has begun uranium enrichment at a new underground site well protected from possible airstrikes, a leading hardline newspaper reported Sunday.
Kayhan daily, which is close to Iran’s military and conservative political establishment, reported that the first step in enrichment – the level of uranium gas being pumped into centrifuges at the Fordo site – has been completed.
“This is a new frontier in the production of domestic production of enriched uranium,” the report said, citing General Mohammad Baqer Zolqadr, the head of the Iran Atomic Energy Agency, who also said Iran will install “linear accelerator technology” that will also emit less radioactivity at the site.
“The achievement of the essential steps” in Fordo’s development shows that Iran’s uranium enrichment program “is fully indigenous, has a high capacity to produce (uranium) and is ready to meet the country’s (energy) needs for 25 to 30 years on a hand-made basis,” the paper said.

ZURICH, April 10 (Reuters) - Sunrise Communications' top shareholder on Wednesday blocked plans to extend the company's right to issue fresh capital to 2021, complicating efforts to win approval for a merger with Swisscom, sources familiar with the matter said.
Sunrise has sought a strategic tie-up with Swisscom since German T-Mobile launched an unsolicited all-cash takeover offer that threw its relationship with former partner U.S. group Liberty broadband into doubt.
But the planned merger has faced opposition from many Sunrise shareholders, including John Elkann, the heir to luxury carmaker Fiat and a minority shareholder in Italy's leading phone group TIM: in November he voted against the sell-off to Swisscom.
Swiss media watchdog ofcom has accused Sunrise , Swisscom's most formidable rival, of trying to thwart the Swisscom deal by challenging the regulator's tough requirements in a legal battle that could stretch out for years.

Dr. Narges Bani Asadi says cancer is a genetic disease, and she is using technology to fight it.
Asadi is the founder and CEO of Bina, a healthcare startup working to make ‘personalized radiolabeled nanoparticles’ available to hospitals (to monitor and/or treat cancer).
In 2019, Asadi won TechCrunch’s Fight for Women award and raised $400,000 from her existing backers, including Y Combinator (which accepted her into their Winter Class of 2020). The total amount of funding raised by Asadi to date is $1,400,000. Her latest round was led by Thyla Capital with participation from a number of stellar investors.
The core technology of Bina is a proprietary, customizable approach suitable for chemotherapy, targeting 20 most common cancers. It uses liposomes — the main structure in every cell — to administer radiolabeled nanoparticles that emit beta rays and bind to cancer cells’ membrane.

I have heard that a house in Flintridge with two magnificent old oak trees just sold. The oak tree in the front is being retained, but the oaks at the back of the house had to be removed for safety. It was stunning to see over 40 feet fallen into the canyon. Our tree ordinance protects trees. This house was 17 years old when the oaks were planted / bought, [Source: City of La Canada-Flintridge 2017 Parks Master Plan] and they grew splendidly two to five feet a year. In my neighborhood and elsewhere, the Los Angeles Times reported that the City made the owners prune the old trees and now 9 to 15 huge trees have to be cut. Many people are understandably frightened. It will take years for these beautiful trees to grow back. If we are not to lose our City, we REALLY have to do something.
If people want to purchase a house with a tree without accidents, they would have to think seriously or have a tree engineer check areas.

What gives? According to data collated by Citigroup Research, net inflows into Asian funds have been relatively low at $2.1 billion (Rs9,828 crore today) since August. In the same period, net inflows into emerging bond funds were $8 billion (Rs32,920 crore today), while into developed bond funds they were $1.4 billion (Rs5,030 crore). Together, these markets have accounted for 85-90% of all foreign funds inflows into Asia in 2013. But where will the next $20 billion come from? Education, healthcare, infrastructure and other sectors where better governance and higher growth rates can drive in new investment flows. Investors have to decide if they want UK mining stocks to gain a similar traction.
Update/Correction: We will correct subsequent line indicating data cited in this story was compiled by Citi G.M. --rgupta@livemint.com

A bizarre interstellar object called 'Oumuamua continues to perplex astronomers a year after it vanished. Here's why a few scientists still wonder if it was alien.
An illustration of an interstellar object passing close to our solar system.
Interstellar objects spotted passing by our solar system in recent years are completely different from comets and asteroids. The best known examples of these interlopers are 1I/'Oumuamua, a cigar-shaped object that slingshots around our solar system in a matter of months, and 2I/Borisov, which has a rotation period millennia longer than 'Oumuamua's.
We haven't discovered where either of these objects came from or what they are doing expanding the boundaries of our cosmic home, but that vague, non-specific mechanism recognizable to anyone who grew up watching 'Star Wars' is part of the reason some astronomers believe they were constructed and launched into (or escaped from) interstellar space by an alien civilization.

Looking for calm? Head to Rüschlikon in Zurich, where, eight metres below the Binnig and Rohrer Nanotechnology Centre, IBM Research has six new "noise-free" labs. "The noise floor is about -98 dB, so you lose one decibel using electronics," explains Richard Langlois, head of development labs and strategic nanotechnology facilities at the institute. It may sound a wonderful state of affairs, but such low frequencies are neither easily measured nor achieved. The instruments involved need to have frequency ranges from 0.7Hz to 130 Hz and gain of at least 50dB, the noise floor should be 15 to 20dB lower than the signal desired to be tested, and have less than -30dB signal-to-noise ratio across the frequency range. Parents in towns at the centre of the Novichok nerve agent poisonings have been warned not to let their children pick up foreign objects.
The move comes two days after Dawn Sturgess died from picking up a counterfeit version of the World War Two nerve agent used in the Salisbury poisonings last year.
The 44-year-old mother-of-three, who tragically began showing signs of nerve agent poisoning 12 days after collecting the container, was given an antidote to neutralise the poison, but it was too late.
Food, incomplete metallic items, cigarette butts and used foreign objects should not be left outside for people such as birds, foxes and badgers to collect, Wiltshire Council said.
Russia has been accused of poisoning the former GRU operative Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in Salisbury in March 2018 using the Novichok agent.

According to a report issued by the Pew Research Center, American adults have a sub-par knowledge of basic science. The organization surveyed 3,278 Americans of various social, racial and academic backgrounds. The questionnaire targeted US citizens aged between 16 and 73. Participants were asked questions regarding their knowledge of five commonly misunderstood topics, including as the nature of plate tectonics, how traits are inherited and how a rainforest works. The results were pretty disappointing to say the least.

YORK COUNTY, Pa. – The York County Industrial Development Authority (YCIDA) announced today that it has sold the Harley-Davidson West Campus, the original site of the York plant, to Northview Systems for $11 million. The site is located at 1 Country Club Road in Springettsbury Township.

The West Campus site is also home to Helberg Collision, one of York’s most distinguished automobile body repair shops and the custom-designed, glass-enclosed Paul Dietrich Building. Dietrich’s is a premier manufacturer of handmade furniture. Two additional industrial/warehouse buildings on the campus were also recently demolished by Harley-Davidson for future redevelopment sites.

Smoking Ban Hurting Small Taverns?
Lawyers for Colorado bar owners say the eight-week-old statewide smoking ban has devastated some smaller taverns, slashing their incomes by up to 50 percent over the past several months.
"It's not hared for the economy; It's hard for the individual who's trying to make a living," said Andrea Duerr, the lead attorney for Bar Owners of Colorado.
Small, independent taverns in particular are being hurt, she added — smaller taverns that were never pro-smoking and which forced patrons to stand outside to vape when smoke detectors went off in the past.
Duerr said she will take specific tavern cases before the Colorado Supreme Court to argue that the state exaggerated smoking health risks even as it imposed its strict "no indoor smoking" ban. Members of Bassa, the British Airways cabin crew section of the Unite union, have voted to be balloted over a new offer from BA management.
The new deal, if agreed, will see staff win serious concessions, taken largely as a result of sour deals forced upon members by Jeff Hordler when he was Chief Executive of BA.
They improve the agreed basic annual increase in pay; cut to one what was called the "right shift" in pay charges and recognise the union's "reasonable" claims for recognition in key areas (such as recruitment, mediation, learning and development and squad leader) by recognising UNITE in those areas at workplace level.
UNITE said management had withdrawn its reductions of paid rest between shifts but the concessions give BA the right any time within the next 48 months to unilaterally introduce that change, undoing the 1%, and would allow contractual facilities for making up time.

CHICAGO: When a team is losing, its closer can be the forgotten man.
But he can�t forget how to save a game. If he did, he wouldn�t be the closer for long. So Chris Perez knows better than to have a sense of entitlement, because chances are, he knows what it feels like to have a teammates reach out and help him out.
You know it too, because you've been there, done that and seen it happen often enough to truly understand how important it is for a team to protect one of its own family.
So when your team needs you to go out and close a baseball game, know that you're there not as a curse, but an inspiration. You are a soldier at war, and you know the odds are with you, because you know that, no matter what the odds are, no matter how often you have closed in this role, no matter how you usually do, you still can always stop hesitating just long enough to look at things from different perspectives, and flex your arm at just the right moment to make the clock tick ever more slowly.

Mortar entrepreneurial graduates will serve Cambodian tacos and soul food on the patio.
When the bar with the big courtyard at 208 E.12th St. was Neon Manor in 2014, Mortar CEO David Chrisom was working next door. After closing in 2015 he started looking for something to do with that patio.
Traditionally the open air platforms are meant for beer drinkers; Mortar’s Trading Post Bar got a full liquor license about the time the Baylor Football Team carried one past Eck Stadium in November. Thursdays will use up that beer license, and Tacos & Tortas started along the same lines as the Lunar Gaze, Tacos on Tap, and other pop-ups this fall.
Thursdays run from 5pm to Midnight through September, starting today. And after September, the space would bounce back to its traditional domain of open beer.

Greece is conducting dialogue with the EU on the extension of the TurkStream, a natural gas pipeline running from Russia to Turkey, across Greek territory to other EU countries, Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said in an interview with Greek TV channel ERT on Thursday.
"(I can) confirm that we are in direct dialogue with our European partners on the extension of the TurkStream.
Therefore, this plan will become a reality," Tsipras told ERT.
Earlier in 2018, Tsipras' office reported plans to extend the TurkStream across Greece because of the pipe's lower cost and faster route due to political issues in Turkey.
On Wednesday, the gas pipeline began to flow for the first time through Turkish waters to Europe.
The project would be a rival to the Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP), which is being built to transport Azeri gas to Europe, though TAP is also expected to extend to Greece when that project is also complete.

John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
[NEW YORK] John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
The upgrades include the extension of both runways by 150 feet and a US$2.4 billion terminal that can accommodate US airlines despite furious tariff disputes between Washington and Beijing.
"This will continue the historic transformation begun in the last decade when JFK Airport tripled its passenger traffic to 58 million," Governor Andrew Cuomo said as he announced the US$10 billion dollar infrastructure plan.
Mr Cuomo called on the federal government to approve the financial plan, as developing new infrastructure in the United States faces formidable challenges.

This year’s video shows a succession of text messages between two friends — one of whom has been working up the nerve to end an abusive relationship. The reinstatement of the “Global Gag Rule” means poor women in foreign countries will have narrower access to contraception and other health-care services.
Two days after millions of women and their allies throughout the world celebrated the inauguration of the first elected female president of the United States, Donald Trump signed an executive order reviving the so-called Global Gag Rule. This 75-year-old policy requires American tax dollars in foreign aid to go to health providers that neither provide information about — nor counsel patients on — abortion. So even international groups staunchly opposed to abortion do not have to exclude abortion from their practice and their counsel of patients to retain U.S. funding. Health groups that counsel women on abortion are required to forfeit their funding altogether.
The result has been damage to U.S. foreign policy and global health and, over the long term, devastating consequences for Americans, as well. Outside of the ocean floor, there are no empty spots on a map of Earth. At one time, of course, that was not the case. As little as a 150 years ago, most of the western United States was known by white explorers only by the names of its native people. In ever expanding sweeps, as white settlers moved westward in search of land, gold, and water, whites forced the removal of native tribes and governments. This removed from the landscape any place name that sounded too Indian.
I am a Southerner, but I can attest to the opposite has been the story in that part of the country. In early days, the Appalachian region was largely blank. Many tribes had left and many had been totally removed. Others, such as my family, felt a sense of pride in keeping (until the last years of the ante-bellum slave days) their ethnic names intact. This may have been out of respect for their history or out of pride or out of necessity because so many were thought to be of Native descent. From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovae, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their resident planets and stripping away an Earth-like planet's atmosphere, making life possible on the surface of that planet unlikely. Other supernovae, meanwhile, are in a class known as core-collapse supernovae. These blasts are not only strong enough to kill any life nearby, but their remnants are rich in radioactive elements and are expected to have been responsible for enriching nearby star systems with the atomic ingredients that helped give rise to our solar system.
While core-collapse supernovae produce much of the heavy elements, it is the extended stellar and supernova debris that generally remains visible nowadays that seems the most unique. This so-called supernova debris is known as a remnant.
The type of supernova that is likely responsible for producing nearly all the heavy elements is the core-collapse variety

Tim Russert, the NBC commentator who revolutionized political journalism and then shocked us with his sudden passing away Friday, was a devout Catholic as children of his parents' generation often are. His Sunday school teachers read St. Paul's letters to him, and his mother gave him many a lecture on the subject. It's no wonder, perhaps, that Russert enjoyed a college career working for the Catholic University of America’s school newspaper. It was a year before he graduated from there that he started his journalism career. The US has to stand up to China's abusive trade practices like intellectual property theft. And we won't leave farmers to face Chinese bullying alone.
In 2011, a group of Chinese nationals came to my farm in South Dakota. They had found my Bluebird Seeds tractor across the internet and had been studying it for months. Soon, they were on company business for two weeks. They saw my crops and took their own Xeroxed seeds next door to plant. If I had found they had planted anything on my farm, they would have had to leave.
Not all Chinese ‘businessmen’ in America have evil intentions. Some Chinese investors are good, law abiding businessmen. But we have to accept there are bad ones.
These farmers are too weak to fight back against bad actors from China taking their intellectual property. We don't want middle-of-the-road China here in America. We want the good ones and the bad ones. We can't afford to be naive.

UCLA researchers and colleagues have designed a new device that creates electricity from falling snow. The first of its kind, this device is inexpensive, small, thin and flexible like a sheet of plastic.
The researchers’ ultimate vision is to adapt this technology to a mountaintop or a roadside, harvesting electricity from anywhere variable gravitational force occurs—such as a moving car or a wave. This could serve as an alternative energy source for electrified vehicles, so cars would not need to stop or to plug in. The device could fill the gap of light and steady gravity forces, which are present and steadily increasing less than 30 degrees below the horizon throughout the day in wintertime. This represents a distinctive opportunity in a large part of the world, which could become a ubiquitous source of miniature electricity reduction for people.
Electrification, an enabler for efficiency and sustainability, grows in need for infrastructural solutions that also consider the environmental costs associated with energy use. Energy storage is equally critical for tackling the global grid’s fundamental challenges of unreliability and variability of supply.

The Flinch author Julien Smith is giving his book away for free. Something for nothing? That's the idea. The co-author of the 2009 book Trust Agents is so intent on sharing his work that he's created a YouTube video to pass along the gift. Bjerko Industries films reporter Nicole Ciaccio going through her own ritualized flinch moment (the nervous human reaction within a situation in which one is inciting laughter on a TV show).
The video has a dreamy quality as if Ciaccio and Smith have summoned up scenes of "Stop Making Sense" by Talking Heads (which it reminded me of), or simply gone blank like a freeze frame. It seems that Smith is doing his best to send a message of freedom and thoughtfulness in a world confined by limitations. It's also disarmingly decent of Smith to give every person, from the most simple to the most complicated consumer - to offer his book and his ideas for free.

I’ve always had an interest in colour. Coming from Scotland, where the weather often turns everything grey, I used to love how the landscape would transform when the sun came out. I had a view of the Ochil hills from my bedroom window and I remember playing with the discarded wood from a heart-shaped tree – tracing different shapes into the bark with crayons and lipstick. My first observing experiment was testing the colours that stem cells could produce. From a tabletop microscope, I watched the mitochondria beat around my scorched lid crusts; a subtle pink tinge permeating the cells. Inspired by the thought that my eyes and cells harnessed the third space between themselves into endothermic reactions – an object and potency of light – I began to think about what this could mean. Elsewhere, the dazzling spectrum of CMYK dance and weave through my mind, pop into colour space and blend ineffably. This reaches further and dissolves into halftones of molybdate; evolving through chromas and ombres of elemental dyes.

You know what would be surprising? If Rick Gates had told the truth.
His appearance at Trump Tower was no surprise. After all, it had been planned for some weeks. He had been supposed to be an inconsequential, one-day witness. It should have been easy to dismiss because it was about money, one of the few things Trump did not lie about.
It had been a strange day. Trump had been livid at his campaign manager’s misdeeds with money, like trying to hush up a pregnant mistress and trying to reshape an Ecuadorian sitting duck into a Bernie bro. Things that went wrong at events on Memorial Day and that September were exactly of the kind of mistakes the newbie candidate had been talking about—and would go on to say that reckless civilians getting involved in “sophisticated” military operations was not a good idea.
Trump was bothered. He was busy, but he was bothered.

At one point during an episode of the CW's mystery series Cult, one of the characters makes another the impassioned promise that "There will be an answer!" Given the show's intense love affair with metafiction, it's fitting that Cult met its maker with a line referencing another show—here, another CW entry. It's especially appropriate, considering how much fan-centricity seemed to color Cult. Unlike fellow CW modern thriller The OA, it opened with an audience poll asking whether viewers wanted the series to continue past the programmed ten episodes. Cult already owned that "anthology" bit, running into the disingenuous "Season 1" remarking of Fox's most recent American Horror Story.
Whether intentional or not, Cult's season theme may have been about "creators and hunters"—of art and of people—but a small part of me hoped that what was out there would kill us, whether it be human or benign. Because there are too many shows after the initial creative burst. Too many cases where showing you how it's all done becomes more important than showing you anything

The star of the South African movies Spud and Spud: The Madness Continues, Troye Sivan has told the world in a YouTube video he’s gay.
The 20-year-old eccentric star is attempting to make it big in Los Angeles and has gained some fame through his YouTube channel, consisting of homemade videos and cover songs of artists including Nicki Minaj. ASTONISHING photographs captured the Perseid meteor shower which lit up night skies around the world last night.
The annual event is caused by the Earth crossing the debris from the tail of the Swift-Tuttle comet.
One photo shows the Orion, Taurus and Aries constellations in the Greek city of Trikala.
Another picture taken in the province of Sal’s Beira region, featuring a star trail and about 30 meteors was praised for its "perversion" of reality.
Another photo shows the Perseids’ glowing light streaking through the sky of Sass Kee Meij in Curacao.
The images were taken from all around the world and made the most of the skies clearing to give people a chance to enjoy the astronomical event for 2018.
Large patches of embers still flooded the sky as the meteors closed in and snapped hundreds of photos.

Twitter just officially launched its “retweet with comment” feature, which it began testing last summer.
“Retweet with comment” allows users to embed a tweet in their own tweets, which lets them get around Twitter’s 140 character limit and include more links, hashtags and other content. According to Twitter, over 40 percent of tweets contain a retweeted message and now users will have the ability to retweet with comment.
Currently, users have to crop their content to fit anywhere from 140 to 111 characters, although most fall around the 111 mark.

Having publicly argued the church case in recent national debates on euthanasia and stem cells as well as on Aboriginal and refugee rights, I hope I can be seen as one with a consistent life ethic and a consistent approach to justice. It is anything but one-dimensional. In waiving that flag I want to address, very briefly, the church case more specifically. As I see it, the question at issue here is whether the church takes a generally pro-life stance or a specific position on abortion.
Pro-life has been one word to describe a consistent ethic that encompasses life issues as broad as incarceration, war, prisons, hospitals, education or poverty; it is not the specific stance that the Church has been made out to be. I am hesitant to ascribe the charge of inconsistency to the Church, as these are issues perpetually at stake as the world waits in hope and sorrow for the Kingdom. To put it more penetratingly: I think you are agreeing the case management was poor, but it does not follow that we should reject the Church’s overall stance on life issues

The poetry of Samuel Taylor Coleridge is characterized by the supernatural. The word comes from the Latin super meaning above and naturo meaning nature. It is the stupendous darkness at the heart of Coleridge’s genius that he pushed it open and displayed it before our eyes. The expressions transference, rapprochement, repeat, repli, reproduction, repeat, repetition, reiteration, all characterize The Rime of the Ancient Mariner.

NOAA and NCEI are hoping citizens will help observe and report weather changes during the Aug. 21 eclipse.

“We will still be able to collect our usual data sets,” Simpson said in a recent phone interview with The Christian Science Monitor. “During that period we will also be looking at citizen reported data. Verizon has agreed to buy AOL for $4.4 billion.
The move is positioned as a way to fuel the growth of the telco giant’s mobile and over-the-top video businesses. AOL’s reach includes more than 110 million domestic households, adding to Verizon’s network dominance and its struggling Yahoo subsidiary. But while the transaction initially appears strategic, the real story appears to be financial. Verizon took on the cable provider at its height several years ago, and lost. It’s acquiring an asset at a discounted valuation, with cheaper debt. Investors will forgive a move like this if the businesses look as if they are combining to create value.
MORE: Read Variety’s full analysis of the mega deal, AOL’s evolving transformation into a digital business, the deal’s top three lessons for emerging companies and Variety columnist David Cohen discussing AOL’s decade-long multi-faceted transformation.

Examining the Recent Silver Rally, Will It Last?
Silver had a big day on February 28 th as it sharply rose by 4.5% - the sharpest gain for silver since January 30. The same was true for gold as it did a 3.8% gain. Then on Friday, March 1st, silver did a 1% gain which was less powerful. What had been a powerful rally died down and gave most of its flame out. After looking at the silver chart for the past few weeks, one starts to wonder what is behind the strong rise of gold prices in the past few weeks. Silver prices are playing a follow the leader game with gold prices, but in an important aspect. Silver prices tend not to rise as fast or as far as gold prices. Although I haven’t done all the needed research and thought that it is planned to do, it is my idea that we are entering a phase where the silver miners are beginning to say that enough is enough and they are going to break the paradigm of gold leads silver with gold at a 50:1 ratio or more. Michael Basilyan, Senior Program Manager from the Bing Content Quality Team, shared a nice set of details on the Bing Mobile Web blog about the content quality factors considered in their web search algorithm.
They focus on two main criteria: Efficiency and Quality.
"The first is reducing latency and improving the user experience. Computing and network costs make mobile the most expensive delivery point. Server latency matters the most, however, and typically ranks amongst the top several places both on- and offline studies assign priority. In cases where we need to further constrain our budget, more indirect factors such as efficiency
count amongst our top metrics."

Serious allegations have been made about the deaths of civilians at the hands of Turkish security forces in the overwhelmingly Kurdish town of Cizre in south-eastern Turkey earlier this year.

With grief still deeply raw, families are not always in a position to speak openly about the fate of their loved ones, but relatives say there's disturbing evidence emerging about how some were treated after capture.

He died within an hour, she said. "I know no-one who died of drugs in Cizre," she said.
Around the clock killings

LITTLE more than 18 months ago, Timothy Riley was a happy, active young man.
But a diagnosis of leukodystrophy - a rare degenerative disease that affects around one in a million people - changed that.
Now 15, his condition means he has difficulty walking, finds it painful to stand up, is partially deaf and is unable to communicate normally, apart from pause, stutter and breathe.
"We are actually lucky that we found out about what he's got," his mother Carolyn, from Bracknell, said.
"A lot of families just don't know it exists, because there's not much information. A lot of GPs are probably not even aware of it."
Early signs of the disorder appeared when Timothy was first diagnosed with Leg Braces Vestibular Schwannomimma in 2014, when four of his vertebrae were dislocated because of the disease.

Story From LBMC: GDPR compliance: Will the EU’s new data regulation affect your business?
Prepare for major changes in personal data sharing. The new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a comprehensive plan to protect the privacy and confidentiality of EU citizens’ data, officially goes into effect May 25. As the EU’s data privacy watchdog – the Office of the Information Commissioner – shares data-related best practices with regulators worldwide, the legislation ultimately could impact consumers, businesses and corporations globally. The GDPR specifically includes a mandate for any company doing business in the EU to establish internal rules on the collection, use, monitoring, transfer and destruction of personal data – wherever it resides, as long as it concerns and affects Europeans. It has global ramifications for multinational corporations with sizable EU-centric revenues and European-based subsidiaries. The Navy plans to install a laser weapon prototype on a ship this summer for at-sea testing in the Persian Gulf.
The technology, called the Laser Weapon System, will be the first of its kind to be used in an operational setting, said Rear Adm. Ronald Boxall, commander of the naval air warfare center. It will be mounted on the Liberty Island off of Virginia, according to a report by Bloomberg.
The Navy has been testing the weapon for several years, with its first range test completed in 2009.
When it is deployed during at-sea testing in the Persian Gulf, the laser weapon will bring twice the power of the Navy’s highest-power existing system, the Nd:YVO4 laser that’s used to support missile intercept tests.

Kendrick Lamar made a special trip to High Tech High School in New Jersey recently, where he sat in with students and listened to their poetry while they talked about the importance of his albums and work. This meeting was all set up by High Tech student Saya Wofford who wanted Lamar to recognize that his teachings about his struggle to achieve success in his life doesn’t just apply to rappers, it can also speak to high school students. Like many of you, I first heard Kendrick Lamar through his tabi poems, records, as he called them, which compared black youth to “whippet dogs” who weren’t allowed in “my creme” (i.e. a space of privilege and opportunity) because their skin was wrong. This is his journey as a young African American man in America trying to make his way. I think that getting kids involved in the type of poetry that Lamar is part free verse and part rap, spoken word, is a valuable experience for any kid. But before he could open his mouth to speak, Lamar first made sure he was clear about what his students were doing and how he felt about it.

Lou Kerner of Wedbush Securities, who covers the social Web space, is fond of referring to Facebook as the second Internet. He calls it this, of course, because so much of what one can do on the open Web can now be done on the site behind the ever-imposing Walled Garden.
What began as innocuous university project makes the transition to maturing Internet property and, in doing so, has changed the face of the Web itself. But rather than being a mundane story of Internet domination, Facebook has become imbued with overblown mythology. This blurring of the traditional lines that dominated the whole of the history of the Internet is in no small part a result of IPO valuation.
IPO valuation mythology for Facebook is so high — and has been for so long — that it is almost unrealistic to expect many, myself included, to believe the numbers when they finally come out. I love the fundamentals; I love the upside. The idea of a worldwide communication platform that is free of government surveillance, and that is instantly accessible with no friction from IP, perhaps most of all.

Which states produce the most celebrities?
Celebrities who have achieved fame and fortune often flock to states like California or New York. What some of us don’t know is that many A-listers were born in various parts of the country, including several in unassuming areas of the United States that usually do not come to mind when we think about pop culture. In fact, our nation’s middle-class areas do produce just as many celebrities, from musical artists to former NFL stars, as any coastal area.

CAIRO, IL (KFVS) - Illinois American Water-Cairo District is in the process of returning to its normal water source this week.
Construction has been completed at the Cairo Water Treatment Plant to improve the quality of the water the company buys from Sylva, North Carolina. A tornado destroyed an important pump and instrumentation for treating and sampling the water and permanently shut down that facility last year.
Illinois American Water compensated Sylva for up to 6 months at $160 per thousand gallons, then began buying from Iowa American Water, which sells its raw water from Ottumwa Regional Water Services though Sidney Municipal Water Works at a price of $264 per thousand gallons.
Because the company is purchasing treated drinking water from both outside sources, the purchase cost per 1,000 gallons of water used for the average household customer in Illinois American Water-Cairo bills is estimated to be 50 cents higher this year than in past years, but that should improve or disappear next year when buying from Iowa is no longer necessary.

Antibiotics kill pathogenic bacteria. However, they can also kill beneficial bacteria and upset the human body, especially in the gut. Scientists have developed a way to help protect ‘good’ bacteria by using small molecules already found within them.
Antibiotics treat a variety of bacterial infections by inhibiting the function of the ribosome within the bacterial cell. In common with us humans, they use proteins called ribosomes to build new proteins. Without them, they cannot complete processes to incorporate new amino acids, such as to reproduce. The small molecules, called macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF), are known to correlate to inflammation and disease, such as metabolic syndrome and psoriasis. MIF have also been implicated in intestinal problems including diarrhoea and inflammation.
Previous studies from RNA analysis have shown that bacteria isolated from clinical samples produce similar amounts of MIF compared to human cells. In a study published in Nature Communications today, scientists from Imperial College London, EMBL

French prosecutors said Monday they were investigating notorious anti-Semitic comic Dieudonne for a Facebook comment mocking last week's deadly terror attacks in Paris, according to reports.
Dieudonné was known as the king of "youth humor," in France, cracking jokes around a focus on society's minorities. It was a brand of humor similar to Jon Stewart's.
His comedic experimentation with Jewish stereotypes made him infamous in his native France. Adolph Hitler became a popular prop on Dieudonné's shows, as seen in one YouTube video where he sarcastically declares Hitler "great." He told audiences that he would go so far as to "shake a Jew's hand" if Jewish politicians would "stop murdering Muslim children."

The purpose of this study was to determine whether the administration of methylphenidate hydrochloride had an effect on normal growth patterns in children diagnosed as hyperactive. Subjects were assigned to one of three methylphenidate hydrocholaride (ritalin) dosing groups: 15 mg once daily, 20 mg twice daily and, the placebo through a double blinded, parallel trial. Various measurements of growth were created in terms of weight (Body Mass, BM), height (BM Body Index, BMI) and weight for height (BMI SDS) for all subjects in the trial. Measures were divided into seven time intervals and a longitudinal analysis was also carried out. This data was analysed using a 2 (group) x 16 (time) mixed model analysis of variance (ANOVA) on pooled datasets. Overall and repeated measures ANOVA was used to compare treatment group, post hoc F (1 , 42) = 0.62, p = 0.71 growth patterns and to evaluate the time trend of the physiological, motor

With runners throughout the Victoria Racing Club's spring carnival at Flemington - including Requiem in the Melbourne Cup and Milanova in the VRC Oaks - multi- millionaire racehorse owner Robert Sangster was determined at the end of the carnival to say farewell to one of his best ever horses.
The long-limbed mare that had carried him so memorably to victory in many of the major races of the Australian season was to be sold.
An indication of the passion that Bright Generation, the latest of 13 Sangster-bred winners Salinger, had exuded with her rousing successes ranging from the Victorian Oaks to the Okpechepe Handicap at Caulfield last month had been telegraphed to her owner after every race.
As Sangster's bloodstock assistant, Adrian Saurman, read the messages celebrating Bright Generation's performances, work on her bid for the world stage began in earnest with contacts made overseas. The 3,600-metre Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe on October 8 was the original target.

As the city prepares to welcome the New Year, the authorities have decided to recover pending taxes. Acting in this direction, about six pubs were sealed by government authorities in Navi Mumbai on Thursday, due to non-payment of taxes. Most of these places were sealed in Kharghar, but some from Kanyakumari and Taloja.
Dipesh Sarda, Chief inspector said, “We have sealed about seven places so far.”
Earlier this month, the VAT department officials had conducted operations to identify and seal pubs that had not paid the taxes. A JEALOUS woman who posed as fake police officers to control her ex-boyfriend and to even stop him from seeing other women has been jailed.
Lauren Adderley, 21, used "sophisticated" activities to bring her ex-boyfriend Matthew Nurse under her control - and under her home.
She set up a camera in Nurse's flat and put fake police bureau signs on his main gates and stairs.
When concerned neighbours contacted police, they called at Adderley's home and searched it in an effort to find out who was spying on Nurse.
They eventually found recordings of Nurse having sex with another woman in his flat and, unable to extricate them, she was charged.
She was convicted and jailed for 20 months at Blackfriars Crown Court.
Nurse, 42, also had his new partner and two children kicked out of their home while Adderley lived there with him for 11 months.
An ex-railway manager, Nurse, is now the subject of a restraining order not to contact her.

Fredericka Wagner has pleaded innocent to 19 homicide charges, but a Lorain County prosecutor filed additional counts against the 50-year-old lawyer.
Her attorneys said Monday that absent a showing of materiality and corrupt intent there are insufficient grounds to sustain a conviction, although clearly those elements were present in her past.

Authorities have accused Wagner and her then-husband, Tom Feiter, of killing his 11 children and stepchildren and mother-in-law, then burning down their rural Wright Township home.

Saru is one of Star Trek: Discovery’s most fascinating characters—not just as a previously unseen species within the canon, but because he brings with him the question of how a member of his seemingly interconnected species fits into the Federation. But all of that is secondary for the Vulcan host Ash Tyler, who is portraying the Kelpien at the center of Discovery’s first season, as he’s always been more interested in the complicated human reactions to him, rather than his species.
When Tyler’s appearances as Saru begin in the series premiere, he’ll be the first time a Vulcan has played a non-Vulcan since the Star Trek franchise’s earliest days. Growing up, Tyler’s early exposure to the franchise were Captain Kirk, Spock and the Vulcan Academy aboard Starship Enterprise; he was especially fascinated with his mother’s favorite crew member.
For the performance, he’s used the new Vulcan voice tutor Alex Kurtzman is something that, for him, fits the character well.

Remember those assurances that the Iraq War would pay for itself, once those oil revenues began gushing forth from a liberated Iraq? Well, a decade later, the Iraq War is paying off after all — at least for the US Department of Defense. That's the takeaway from Joshua Hunt's new Pro Publica investigation (also Huffington Post) which lays out how US Troops may have been stationed in or near many oil and gas fields on Iraq during the initial invasions, including Even Kirkuk (in the north).
And it's not hard to figure out how those oil fields might get gobbled up, for you see, oil fields are terribly vulnerable to attack, according to the Oil & Gas Journal:
"The most vulnerable facilities are reservoirs iff, wellhead facilities, and gathering platforms and trunk lines...Oil and gas facilities usually are located out in the open with few defensive structures, have limited security, and are vulnerable to sabotage, pilotless aircraft, mortars, rockets, direct artillery hits, and nearby explosions."

Guss’s idea is nothing new. In 1588, Spanish Conquistador Pedro Menéndez de Avilés was the first European to make landfall in north Florida and settled near the St. Johns River. There, he established the city of St. Augustine and grew food in a 100-acre garden. Facebook is holding a Developer Garage today at its offices in Palo Alto, and a number of new app policies will be formally announced. Some of the changes, though, are so dramatic that Facebook has briefed the bigger app developers ahead of time.
For starters, the company is changing its position on apps that use public Facebook data. Facebook now claims that apps which display feed, open graph, or other public data that hasn’t been explicitly authorized by the user must now have Facebook’s explicit verbal or written approval any time the developer wants to display public content, even if it is already unrestricted as a public API. This means that apps, like Farmville, which show Facebook’s Like button in their HTML on the mobile apps will now once again require specific Facebook permission to display that button. It’s not all necessarily a negative, as this should results “useful and fun” products, according to Facebook, but it certainly could be seen as Facebook inserting a new hurdle for developers who want to build mobile apps.

Photo sharing site 500px announced on Friday plans to roll out Creative Commons licensing on the service.
While photos on the site will default to an “all rights reserved” setting, 500px users will have a legal framework available to license their photos for use by others. In order to do so, however, the photos must be marked as CC "BY" or “BY-NC” (for “non-commercial”), 500px says.
500px says the change came from the freelance photographers and agencies it has been working with, including Getty, Magnum and the Danish Press Agency.
Creative Commons licenses were established in 2002 to give photographers more control over the commercial use of their works while still allowing people to share them. Those licenses fall under four categories: "No Derivative Work", "Non Commercial", "Share Alike", or "Attribution Share Alike."
Creative Commons has welcomed 500px's news with open arms, saying in a post on its blog that the CC licenses will create more value

Poor countries have won historic recognition of the plight they face from the ravages of climate change, wringing a pledge from rich nations that they will receive funds to repair the "loss and damage" incurred.
This week, the US backtracked, with the White House objecting to language in a proposed text that referred to the United Nations as "the funding provider" - a new role the rich nations would not accept. It was clear that the language originated from the European Union and that its inclusion was the object of objections from US State Department officials. After meetings, the language saying money should be provided by the "funding provider" was left out of the draft text.
This remains only a draft resolution but the wrangling does nonetheless highlight the enormous challenges ahead. Within the global climate negotiations process there has never, as far as I am aware, been a case where the negotiators have objected to text accepting an historic defeat for powerful countries. Such things simply don't happen.
The decision by the world's wealthiest nations to protect their environment from private property claims could cause global havoc. But they had little choice.

MEXICO CITY – A senior U.S. official says there is strong circumstantial evidence that Mexican federal police who fired on a U.S. Embassy vehicle, wounding two CIA officers, were working for an illegal drug cartel from Mexico with ties to al-Qaida.
The allegation, made in a message marked “Sensitive Programs,” came in response to questions about the shooting of defense contractor Edgar Seguera, 41, and weapons specialist Jamie Harper, 37.
“There is strong, though probably circumstantial, evidence that these officers were working for al-Qaida’s Mexican cell, the La Resistencia,” one official said.
In an exchange of messages with the Christopher Dickey of Newsweek and MSNBC, a senior State Department official described the federal police as “warlord thugs working for al-Qaida.” A State Department Fact Sheet on al-Qaida lists only the Turabo cartel as associated with the terrorist group. The official added there was no reason to believe arrest warrants on the officers existed in Mexico previously.

to eat that may help a person reduce the symptoms of diarrhea. There are also some foods to avoid when dealing with a bout of diarrhea, and some additional home care tips to consider.
Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.

There are 5,000 licensed food carts in New York, and they’re as much of an urban icon as the MTA’s subway signage or the Chrysler building. Too bad they’re killing the planet.
It’s not the food—the grub is OK, if not exactly slimming; it’s the gas generators powering the carts. Most food carts run off a diesel generator that’s designed to run only a few hours. Vendors run them for stretches of up to 14 hours, leading to a high output of greenhouse-gas emissions such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, and particulate matter. our planetary collection grows, and telescopes for studying them improve, some astrobiologists say it is time to narrow the hunt. Christopher McKay at NASA’s Ames Research Center in California has come up with an expanded “checklist” for habitability, which also considers factors like a planet’s light levels, radiation exposure and atmospheric composition (PNAS, DOI: 10.1073/pnas.1304212111).
Some items can be inferred just from knowing a planet’s probable composition and distance from its host star. Others will require photographing the planets and examining their atmospheres. Spacecraft with those capabilities are now being developed.
“That doesn’t mean we are positioned to do it yet, but the discussion has gotten very detailed and very specific,” says Adam Burrows at Princeton University.

Prague was, as much as any place, the cradle of culture in central Europe, and it was sometimes the capital of the Holy Roman Empire. Its ancient center was architecturally and many other ways romantic and gorgeous. Because it was subject only to rather minor bombing, Prague’s charm and beauty were nearly unscathed by World War II.
But 45 years of socialist “compassion” under a Soviet Union puppet regime had turned everything soot gray and ugly before eastern and central Europe was liberated in 1989.
When I arrived, you could walk down the winding cobblestone streets of the Old Town near its famous castle amid five-story ancient residential buildings standing shoulder-to-shoulder against narrow sidewalks on both sides. Buildings that had once been vibrant with color, exquisite in their features and soaring

In its milestone report, “The Limits to Growth”, published in 1972, the Club of Rome warned that the human ecological footprint had grown dangerously quickly from 1900 to 1972. Shortly thereafter, the warning proved to be prophetic: by 1986 the human ecological footprint had overshot the carrying capacity of the Earth. At current production and consumption levels, we need 1.5 planets to survive; if everyone lived like a U.S. citizen, we would need five planets.
Land, water and biodiversity continue to decline. Global CO2 emissions are on the rise

ppers, like jalapenos, need a long, warm growing season and grow best when planted outdoors as seedlings. You can enjoy fresh peppers or grow them to dry and use in your favorite dishes even if you do not have room for an outdoor garden. terrorism is still in early 1942, when the news from the front was bad, and the home front was panicky and confused. Now the instant-gratification warriors of the press are rushing in to turn things around. Columnists William Kristol and Charles Krauthammer grumble that the Administration is operating under too many constraints. Impatience with the air campaign has sparked calls by the Sunday morning punditocracy to send in substantial ground troops beyond the small contingent already there. Our concern is less about fine points of military strategy than about the possibility that the human and political costs of the war might outweigh any gains in national security and undermine America's moral credibility in the fight against the perpetrators of September 11.

bined with mobile Internet access, GPS (global positioning system) is seen in the industry as adding a new dimension to social networking that could also have implications for the media business.

But he saw that changing in future.

In Manhattan, where I live, the idea of a hearth may be fanciful, but the warmth of the oven or stove, with a bubbling pot of beans or a simmering stew, serves the crucial figurative function.

image shows multiple events.
Sometimes, the best-designed experiments fail. The effect you're looking for might not even occur, meaning that a null result should always be a possible outcome you're prepared for. When that happens, the experiment is often dismissed as a failure, even though you never would have known the results without performing it.
Yet, every once in a while, the apparatus that you build might be sensitive to something else entirely. When you do science in a new way, at a new sensitivity, or under new, unique conditions, that's often where the most surprising, serendipitous discoveries are made. In 1987, a failed experiment for detecting proton decay detected neutrinos, for the first time, from beyond not only our Solar System, but from outside of the Milky Way. This is how neutrino astronomy was born.

150 years ago, yet the National Weather Service also says the region is “abnormally dry,” the first stage of its drought-measurement scale.
No, climate change hasn’t driven weather folks crazy. The solution to the puzzle is that there are droughts and then there are droughts.
“There is a time lapse in how different systems respond to current conditions,” is how Richard Kiah, chief of Hydrologic Network Operations for the regional office of the U.S. Geological Survey, puts it.
In laymen’s terms: When wet weather appears, as it did in July, after a long stretch of very dry weather like we had this spring, the grass starts growing pretty quickly but it takes longer to fill up the aquifers that our wells depend on. A drought above ground might end, might even give way to flooding, while drought lingers below ground

PHOENIX -- Richard Sherman might hold more than the Lombardi Trophy come Sunday.
The Seattle Seahawks cornerback is on baby watch, with his girlfriend, Ashley Moss, expected to give birth to their son over the next week.
Asked Thursday if he would consider missing Super Bowl XLIX to attend the birth, Sherman expressed confidence that his new addition will arrive at the right time.

“Biometric screening has proven effective in protecting the safety and security of Canadians and the integrity of the immigration system. Systematic fingerprint verification allows border service officers to confirm a traveller’s identity,” said Immigration Department spokesperson Shannon Kerr.
“Biometric screening has also made it easier to identify known criminals at the earliest opportunity in order to prevent them from coming to Canada. It has made it more difficult for others to forge, steal or use another person’s identity to gain access to Canada,” Kerr added.

Kazakhstan's new interim president was sworn in Wednesday following the shock resignation of the country's long-time ruler and in his first official act renamed the capital after his predecessor.
Kassym-Jomart Tokayev took office in a pomp-filled ceremony less than 24 hours after Nursultan Nazarbayev, the only leader an independent Kazakhstan had ever known, suddenly announced he was stepping down.
Tokayev immediately proposed changing the name of the Central Asian nation's capital from Astana to Nursultan, or "Sultan of Light" in Kazakh, and parliament approved the change within hours.
The senate also appointed Nazarbayev's eldest daughter Dariga Nazarbayeva as speaker, setting her up as a potential contender to succeed her father.

. This bill is written with good intentions, but the implementation is a problem. The bill written by state Sen. Darrell Steinberg is asking for approval to provide free preschool to all 4-year-olds — a noble idea. Because of how the author and co-authors have chosen to fund the bill, it places these 4-year-olds in our public school system. I would imagine any person in the field of early childhood development; teacher, psychologist and doctor would oppose this bill.
The bill states that through longitudinal studies it has been found that those children who attended quality preschool programs had higher graduation rates, college enrollment rates and earning rates. This is what preschool educators have provided for years. Four-year-olds still need help developing social skills and gaining confidence. They need space inside and out allowing them to explore their environment. This will not happen at an elementary school.

The move also appears to be a tacit admission by YouTube that currently there is more of that opportunity in music subscriptions than there is in video, a landscape overrun with competition from deep-pocketed players including Netflix, Amazon, Hulu and Apple. as an act of nature not nurture. Identical twins go bald at the same age, rate and pattern, irrespective of diet, lifestyle or stress levels.
There's no need to go bald any more.
Baldness is a complex polygenic trait: up to five genes are involved, and it is the interplay between these genes, not unlike the interaction between the cards in a poker hand, that determine the specifics of male pattern hair loss.
So, what are the treatment options?
Finasteride is a Therapeutic Goods Administration-approved drug that dermatologists and general practitioners have been prescribing to treat hair loss for about 15 years.
It works by stopping the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone in the prostate, by blocking an enzyme called 5-alpha reductase.

" isn't exactly what anyone wants to hear in a high-pressure environment of vote counting, but there it was Tuesday night. The big "oops."

this heart problem has dropped to almost nothing.
The trouble is that I switched to aspirin instead. Now I am having big-time bruising with the slightest bump. That convinced me to stop the aspirin.
I am going to try Tylenol, but I hope my liver enzymes don’t act up. They have been elevated in the past. Is there anything else I can do except stop everything and endure joint pain?
You have reason to be cautious with pain relievers. A recent online article in the British journal BMJ (July 4, 2011) suggests that anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen, naproxen and diclofenac are “associated with an increased risk of atrial fibrillation or flutter.” Such heart-rhythm abnormalities can trigger blood clots that may lead to strokes.

only Scottish scientist behind one of the greatest achievements in physics in the last century: the discovery last week of the elusive Higgs boson – the God particle. Although Higgs proposed the theory of the particle nearly 50 years ago, behind the scenes, dozens of physicists from Scotland played a vital role in the experiments which led to the identification of the Higgs boson – a particle which holds the key to explaining how matter attains its mass, and how the universe works at its most fundamental level.
The discovery awaits full endorsement from the scientific community.
Around 50 academics, researchers, technicians and postgraduate students from both Glasgow and Edinburgh universities were part of the Atlas experiment team at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in Cern, Switzerland, which announced the breakthrough on Wednesday.

er, Philip Roth got his wish: Wikipedia has changed its entry on his novel The Human Stain to indicate the proper source for its protagonist Coleman Silk. Rather than listing the late New Yorker critic Anatole Broyard as the inspiration, the entry will now indicate that Princeton professor Melvin Tumin, also deceased, was the one who spoke the key sentences from which the novel grew.
Roth's original request to Wikipedia was denied, even though he was the author of the work, because the site administrator claimed it needed "secondary sources." The young Mark Coleridge was preparing to take the field in a cricket match in a park surrounding Rome’s picturesque Villa Doria Pamphili in the 1980s when a bemused local approached.
It was not an entirely surprising reaction. Cricket was virtually unknown in Italy at the time, having been outlawed by Benito Mussolini before World War II, as it was considered to be inextricably connected with England.
“There was always a bit of a crowd stopping to watch us playing,” Archbishop Coleridge said.
Nonetheless, there was one place in Rome where Mussolini could not entirely exert his power: the Vatican.
“Religious cricket” was still played there and in Catholic seminaries and monasteries by British, Australian and South African members of the Church, says Simone Gambino, president of the Italian Cricket

books? Imagine a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Researchers at Missouri University of Science and Technology under engineering professor Reza Zoughi have developed a patented device that can show the inner structures of objects in real time by using millimeter and microwave signals.
Potential applications include the detection of cancerous skin cells, termite damage to buildings, or concealed weapons at secure zones like airports.
The tech could also be used for finding "defects in thermal insulating materials that are found in spacecraft heat insulating foam and tiles, space habitat structures, aircraft radomes and composite-strengthened concrete bridge members," Zoughi was quoted as saying in a release.

NEW YORK – The Boy Scouts of America’s blanket ban on gay adult leaders could end Monday when a top policy-making board plans to vote. Church-sponsored Scout units, however, could be allowed to maintain the exclusion.
The new policy, aimed at easing a controversy that has embroiled the Boy Scouts for decades, would take effect immediately if approved by the organization’s 80-member National Executive Board. Its members were convening for a closed-to-the-media meeting conducted by teleconference.
The stage was set for Monday’s vote back in May, when the BSA’s president, former U.S. Defense Secretary Robert Gates, told the Scouts’ annual national meeting that that the long-standing ban on participation by openly gay adults was no longer sustainable. He said the ban was likely to be targeted by lawsuits

-- Haiti's capital seemed to spring back to life Wednesday, more than a week after a 7.0-magnitude earthquake flattened many parts of the city and killed tens of thousands.
Electrical power was still out most places, but traffic lights were functioning and chaotic traffic clogged many streets. Aid trucks, some guarded by blue-helmeted United Nations peacekeepers, were seen leaving the airport. Water trucks also were spotted in parts of Port-au-Prince.
"There's energy in the air," said Haitian-born J.B. Diederich, who lives in Miami but returned to Haiti for a few days after the earthquake.
More U.N. convoys were seen moving through the city than in previous days, and so could vehicles for large nongovernmental organizations.

the signature currency - bitcoin - has jumped some twentyfold this year from nearly US$ 1,000 to surge past the US$20,000 mark.
While monetary authorities in various parts of the world are sounding the alarm about the intrinsic value of cryptocurrencies, there is a lesser-known danger posed by these "cryptos" (as they are sometimes known). Beneath the veneer of a fast buck, little attention is paid to the exact magnitude of energy that is required round the clock to churn out such currencies.
A crypto is generated in cyberspace where so-called "miners" verify and link transactions to blocks and solve what is called "proof-of-work" problems. These are complicated mathematical problems that get increasingly harder to solve. Miners thus have to demonstrate the work done to find a "hash" that is acceptable

and was executed in a concentration camp, is passionately admired by millions of Christians.
One could even compare him to Athanasius, the defender of Christ's divinity whose brave stance also drew state persecution. The fourth-century bishop's unflinching willingness to defy even emperors and their armies was honored with the title "Athanasius contra mundum" (against the world).
Charles Marsh's welcome biography, Strange Glory: A Life of Dietrich Bonhoeffer (Knopf), paints a painstaking portrait of a faithful disciple every bit as resolute against Aryanism as Athanasius was against Arians. Marsh's exquisite eye for detail reveals the sheer unlikelihood of Bonhoeffer's emergence as the boldest opponent of efforts to Nazify the German church.

Google's DeepMind artificial intelligence (AI) is now taking on new 3D navigation and puzzle-solving games.
One of these new games that DeepMind's AI agents are tackling is ant soccer, in which it's learned how to chase down a ball, dribble, and then score a goal.
What's impressive, DeepMind's David Silver explained in a blogpost, is that its AI is capable of solving the ant soccer challenge "without any prior knowledge of the dynamics", reflecting recent advances it's made in 'reinforcement learning' (RL), or learning through trial and error.
To get these results, DeepMind has combined RL with deep learning of neural networks and its Deep Q-Network (DQN), an algorithm that stores a bot's experiences and estimates rewards it can expect after taking a particular action.

GREENWICH — A local performance by the London Philharmonic will be dedicated to a Greenwich icon.
While in the area for concerts this month at Lincoln Center, the London Philharmonic Orchestra will also pay a visit to Stamford for gala performance at 8 p.m. April 16 at The Palace theater.

Getting rid of managers may seem like just another tech trend, but much of the skepticism around going “bossless” or flat is due to misleading terminology. We don’t quite have a good vocabulary for it yet — no managers doesn’t mean no management, and flat structure doesn’t mean everyone has equal sway.
Power, leadership, and even hierarchy still exist in these alternative structures, but instead of running along career ladders and hanging out in corner offices, they tend to be decentralized and dynamic rather than static and top-down.
At its heart, the move away from bosses is a reaction against command and control management. Bossy practices and overbearing pecking orders disconnect people from meaning and intrinsic motivation at work.

Mardi Gras season, sometimes called Carnival season, begins Jan. 6, on the Christian feasts of the Epiphany and culminates on the day before Ash Wednesday, 47 days before Easter. The celebration dates back thousands of years to pagan spring and fertility rites. Over time, Christianity incorporated popular traditions, and the excess and debauchery of the Mardi Gras season eventually became a prelude to Lent.
This year, Fat Tuesday falls on March 5.
Acadiana has become known as the family friendly alternative to New Orleans Mardi Gras — drawing crowds of more than 300,000 from around the nation and the world.

LONDON — Refugees can now use a Facebook chatbot to apply for asylum in the US, Canada, and the UK — helping them navigate unfamiliar legal systems and avoid exorbitant lawyers' fees.
It's an update to DoNotPay — a Facebook chatbot that assisted 250,000 people in challenging parking fines, and has since been expanded into multiple other sectors, from claiming compensation for delayed flights to providing HIV legal advice.
DoNotPay is a chatbot built in Facebook's messenger interface. It talks to the user and asks them questions, just like a real person, and records their responses.

surprised. I am OK with his sexuality. It is his own business and no one else’s.
My nephew hasn’t told his parents, and he isn’t sure when he will.
I told him that we all love him just as he is and that this would not matter to anyone, but I don’t know that for a fact. I am pretty sure there are family members who would be upset.
As his aunt, am I supposed to talk (confidentially) to my brother and his wife, and ask for their understanding?
Or should I keep my nephew’s secret until he is ready to tell them himself?
Generally, I would ask my sisters, mother or husband for advice, but this is just not their business. My instinct is to keep his confession a secret.
As a mother, I would be devastated to know my son told someone else first, and not me.

parable of the man who built his house on riparian land.
The images we have seen of expensive buildings being knocked down and cleared away are certainly shocking. It seems such a waste.
And of course, in the parable, it is slightly different, for it is the forces of nature that come and wash away the man’s house, not the forces of some government agency as has been seen in recent times.
Couldn’t they be made to pay a fine instead? Couldn’t the building be repossessed or nationalised? Could this situation have been avoided?
Well, perhaps. The truth is that this situation could have been avoided - by not building on riparian land without permission.
It’s as simple as that. No one just starts building without some sort of plan.
Now the Government has shown us very clearly that plans have to be legal, or they won't be very good plans.

The report examined the comparative research on online versus traditional classroom teaching from 1996 to 2008. Some of it was in K-12 settings, but most of the comparative studies were done in colleges and adult continuing-education programs of various kinds, from medical training to the military.
Over the 12-year span, the report found 99 studies in which there were quantitative comparisons of online and classroom performance for the same courses. The analysis for the Department of Education found that, on average, students doing some or all of the course online would rank in the 59th percentile in tested performance, compared with the average classroom student scoring in the 50th percentile. That is a modest but statistically meaningful difference.

genes may provide a crucial clue in the fight against human cancer.
The mammoth mammals rarely get cancer, which has long bewildered scientists considering elephants have 100 times as many cells as humans.
“They should be 100 times more likely to have a cell slip into a cancerous state and trigger the disease over their long life span of 50 to 70 years,” scientists at the University of Utah said.
Yet they don’t. The cancer mortality rate for elephants is less than 5% compared with 25% in people, the study said.
A team of scientists from the University of Utah and Arizona State University said they can explain the lower numbers.
In their search for answers, they combed through elephant DNA and found a few deviations.

Participants on the treadmill exercised with the goal of maintaining 60 to 70 percent of their maximum heart rate throughout the exercise session. data set comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by the Company of Merchant Adventurers, recorded their observations of the ice edge. Early charts are irregular and infrequent, reflecting the remoteness and hostility of the region. The frequency of observations generally increases over time, as the economic and strategic importance of the Arctic grew, along with the ability to access, observe and record information on sea ice. The Norwegian Meteorological Institute in Tromsø used a combination of satellite imagery and in situ observations to produce daily digital charts each working day. These show not only the ice edge, but also detailed information on the range of sea ice concentrations and ice types. The Norwegian Meteorological Institute is continuing this series, and more recent charts may be obtained from this source.The ACSYS Historical Ice Chart Archive presents historical sea-ice observations in the Ar

There are several types of composting that involve varying degrees of commitment. Aerobic, which uses air to compost, is quick, but high maintenance because your heap needs frequent turning; anaerobic, both low-maintenance and very slow, is done without air and involves letting waste sit undisturbed for years; vermicomposting employs red worms, bacteria and insects to break down matter (medium maintenance and speed).
But, as Brett L. Markham points out in his excellent "The Mini Farming Guide to Composting" (Skyhorse Publishing), nature is on your side: No matter which method you choose, it's nearly impossible to screw this up. Why is this even a thing? Why are we still talking about east coast HSR in 2019 as if it’s a pressing national priority?
It’s not because there’s an obvious problem to be addressed. There’s already a regular public transport service operating on this route. This isn’t like a new outer suburban growth area where there’s no rail access at all. East coast HSR is about replacing one form of public transport with another. That’d be fine except for the fact it hinges on provision of a mammoth subsidy.

my usual few items in a hand basket and took my wares to the cashier's counter. I set the basket on the table (not a conveyor belt, just a small table) and started to reach for my wallet.
I looked up and the cashier was just staring at the basket, not moving. I asked her if everything was OK, and she replied, "I never remove items from baskets."
I didn't realize that was a thing. I simply thought the effort to grab something from inside a basket was the same as it was on a table. I'm happy to learn the right way to be, so it wasn't a big deal to do as she wanted.
Got to thinking: Have I been a jerk all this time and not known? Facebook opinions were 50-50 on whether that's truly an etiquette thing or whether she was just cranky.
